componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Cameron Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Lamb, Vice President, Investor Relations for Cameron. Thank you, Mr. Lamb, you may begin.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; and Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and C
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; and Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and, as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's Annual Report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share for continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share for continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of our Drilling and Surface segments along with a significant reductio n in the company's overhead expense. Most notably, our Drilling segment reported a 89% increase in operating income and an almost 700 basis point improvement in margin relative to the year-ago quarter.
While the Surface business reported a 23% increase in operating income, consolidated SG&A expense declined 11% relative to the year-ago quarter. On a consolidated basis, these factors contributed to an operating income margin of 15% for Cameron. 
Additionally, the company generated $938 million of cash from operations during the quarter, an increase of 49% compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 and reflected in part our sharpened focus on reducing working capital.
Overall, 2014 was a great year for Cameron on a number of fronts. Most impressive was the turnaround story with our Drilling Systems. As previously mentioned, we saw a 700 basis point improvement in margins versus year-ago levels. Even more importantly, we have now embedded both processes and work practices that have driven predictable success in executing our backlog.
We are also very pleased with the timing and the outcome of the divestiture process with compression. Not only did we generate $1.5 billion of sales proceeds, it also allowed us to sharpen our focus on Cameron's core oil and gas businesses.
We implemented a number of cost reduction programs that began the process to streamline our support structure across all of our business units, which proved to be meaningful contributor to improving overall margins. We returned $1.7 billion of cash to shareholders in 2014, while maintaining a very healthy balance sheet.
And the momentum we created with investing and broadening the platform of our core businesses will benefit us in a market where customers' attention turns cost and efficiency versus just availability.
Now some comments regarding outlook for 2015, and I will start with our own store markets. Fairly, we are witnessing a very sharp correction in activity that will negatively impact our Surface, Valves and Drilling segments in 2015. North America will be impacted much harder than international. The degree to which North America activity correct is still unknown. The range of possibilities will be heavily influenced by both the customer and the basin. Cameron has a broad presence in North America and we have a very broad customer base. Mostly populated without sees, major independents and the major drilling contractors, all of which we se as a positive to have in this environment.
Cameron also has a very large international onshore presence, which will contract, at a slower rate, and in some markets, could even expand. Cameron's customer base is made up mostly of large OCs and NOCs whose attitudes towards investing through cycles have proven to be more predictable. 
As for our offshore in deepwater markets, OneSubsea Drilling Systems and valve markets will all be exposed to the pullback in spending we are witnessing offshore as well.
We saw the pause about hit on most deepwater drilling capital spending last year and nothing in our views has changed with the exception the we are not seeing drilling contractors actually scrap older generation rigs, something we have rarely seen in prior year cycles, which in time is a positive for some form of newbuild recovery.
We will see some compression in the services part of our businesses due to lower reutilization and pricing, but we also see opportunity to serve a broader portfolio of products from our rig equipment acquisitions.
As for Subsea projects of every perspective project we are tracking has or is going through recalibration process for both scope and price. Some of this work actually started last year. While we fully expect to see projects award in 2015, the value or the result of these exercises maybe different front what we were thinking 6 [ph] months ago. 
The importance of Deepwater projects in our customers' portfolios have not changed. The timing on which 1 cycle to the forefront in the current cost environment will, which I'll place to the strength that OneSubsea was created to deliver.
Having said all of that, I'll remind you that Cameron has a substantial backlog of work. And that backlog provides us with good visibility and to a portion of our 2015 operating revenues and margins. And our confidence to deliver that backlog at the margins and in the time frame we have in our plan is very high, given the performance we've seen throughout 2014.
However, we will see our equally, if not more important, shorter cycle booked and built businesses meaningfully impacted by the current environment. And the speed in which we have seen the correction in this cycle over the past months has created significant uncertainty with the degree that this will impact both the revenues and margins of our short-cycle businesses, especially those in North America.
Given we're still very early in the cycle, it wd be challenging to predict the range of outcomes within our budget and, therefore, feel it's prudent not providing annual EPS guidance for 2015. Chuck will, however, provide detailed commentary on each of our operating segments.
While trying to speculate on the depth and duration of the cycle, our action will be difficult. Rest assured that Cameron will stay very close to our customers to ensure we are advancing and investing the most cost efficient solutions for their operations, not compromise on our commitment to service and execution excellence, aggressively manage our call structure to the reality of the business and be opportunistic towards expanding our core platforms. You can also expect us to leverage our broad product, customer and geographic diversity to expand share. Every operator is currently reviewing their supplier's performance to ensure that they have the most cost-effective partner in this environment and that will open doors for Cameron.
This competitive drive will help us weather this cycle as we have weathered previous cycles and emerge as even more formidable company over the longer term.
I will now turn over the discussion over to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I'd like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. We've ever had our safest year ever while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structure
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I'd like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. We've ever had our safest year ever while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structure down every quarter in 2014 while performing at this record activity rate. Focus on execution, cost reduction and servicing our customers results in strong margin progression throughout the year.
Fourth quarter results were a culmination of a lot of hard work and diligence that positions the enterprise in a better place to perform on the challenges that we face in 2015.
Now let's switch gears to the present in 2015. Weak macro environment, as Jack described, is certainly evident when you look at Cameron's orders in backlog position in the fourth quarter of 2014. Our book-to-bill ratio in the quarter was 0.7:1 as order intake declined in all of our businesses on a sequential quarter basis. There will, however, a couple of bright spots of customer activity during the fourth quarter. In particular, we booked a multiyear contract with ExxonMobil for topside wellhead equipment and production trees for the Hevron project, a 52-well development located offshore Newfoundland, as well as OneSubsea's execution of OneSubsea well intervention alliance with Helix and Schlumberger. Nevertheless, the order flow was weak and the net result of that was a decline in our backlog throughout the [ph] $9.5 billion at the end of the quarter.
Despite the reduction in backlog, the backlog itself is substantial, especially in our larger cycles businesses, OneSubsea and Drilling. The organization is highly focused on our ability to execute our backlog and the operational improvements realized in 2014 will carry over into 2015.
As Jack said, in this challenging macro environment, Cameron is absolutely focused on the things they can control. We are committed to our objective of delivering steady improvement in our consolidated operating margins on average over time. To be clear, over a multiyear period, some of this improvement could be temporarily masked by pricing pressure and reduced volumes, but we are confident in our ability to keep advancing this program over the long term and driving excellence in our ability to execute.
We are seeking to do this through continuous improvements in virtually every aspect of our operations from our supply chain to product delivery and throughout our corporate and support services organizations. We're finding ways to work smarter, faster and more efficiently and more creatively interesting we do. 
We also want to make sure that we're operating at maximum cost effectiveness. The cost reduction steps were taken in 2014 are helping us prepare for 2015. We will and have already taken further cost reductions in the first quarter and we will continue to aggressively drive our cost structure down throughout the year as we work off [indiscernible] backlog.
In addition to volume reduction, the other challenge we are facing is pricing. The majority of our customers are seeking or have already asked for price concessions to help them weather the current environment. And Cameron's response to this request has been a proactive and collaborative approach. We are working to the customers to drive improved technology and processes that will reduces their overall spending commitments in their operating costs. We feel that the largest cost savings for operators will come from a drive towards standardization, improved technology and further customer integration. We are in the early days but we are already seeing a few wins with this approach.
Each of our businesses have different drivers and behave differently throughout the down cycle. Having completed our divestiture program in 2014, we are committed to each of our 4 operating segments and I'm confident that we will emerge through this cycle better than ever.
OneSubsea will continue to build on the quarter [ph] process approach that will help operators improve their overall recovery in their deepwater developments. We continue to progress in this endeavor and operators will need help to find a cost effective solutions to generate higher production from the Deepwater assets.
Or Surface division is well positioned as the market leader to continue to outperform in a relative basis and grow market share by providing the highest service level and the best reliability in the industry.
In Drilling, we will take this opportunity in the downturn to complete a comprehensive and integrated drilling offering. The Valves & Measurement segment touches everything we do in Cameron in every segment of our businesses. We will leverage the bright knowledge within the enterprise to ensure that Valves & Measurement outperforms in this business cycle.
While we're actively realistic facing the current market situation, Cameron's poised to take advantage of the opportunities that will present themselves. We're being very proactive in our approach to manage oru customers and their cost structure. We have a highly engaged team and we have a relentless drive towards excellence.
The activities and programs that we're [indiscernible] now will position Cameron for long-term success and outperformance throughout the cycle. 
I'll now turn it over to Chuck for the financials.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts our models. Revenues for the quarter wer
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts our models. 
Revenues for the quarter were $2.8 billion, a 5% increase sequentially. Segment operating income margins were 15% for the quarter, flat sequentially but up 200 basis points from prior year level. Corporate expenses for the quarter were $35 million and EPS for the costs of $1.34, an all-time [indiscernible] of a record.
The key message in our fourth quarter financials is our operating margin improvement we've made throughout 2014. The improvements have come from better efficiency in our plans as well as tight control over our costs and these will serve us well during the downturn.
Subsea revenues increased 12% sequentially, whilst operating margin improved to 10%, reflecting the strength of our margin in backlog. We're pleased with the sequential progression to recognize the need to continue to grow were services offering in this segment to further enhance margins.
Our Surface revenues increased 10% sequentially and represented the highest revenue level in our history, driven primarily by North America. This operating margin improved 110 basis points sequentially, driven by the higher revenue level as well as improved mix in North America.
Drilling revenues increased 2% sequentially. To give you some perspective on the improvements Drilling has made over the last 12 months, the fourth quarter revenue is 20% higher than it was in the year-ago period. Operating margin for Drilling was 18.5%, which is below the previous quarter simply due to mix. The fourth quarter operating margin is 850 basis points higher than the low point we saw in Q1 of this year.
V&M revenues decreased 5% sequentially as it has struggled with orders and pricing in its engineered valve line all year. As a result, we were hit hard this quarter with absorption challenges and lower margin engineered valve shipments, which resulted in a decline in Q4 operating margin to 15.3%. We're in the midst of completing a realignment of this segment, which will allow us to capture additional market share while lowering our costs at the same time.
Cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter was $938 million, obviously a record level, as our working capital efficiency drive begins to show results. As a result, we ended the year with $1.6 billion of cash and short-term investments. As we announced earlier in the month, we completed our sale of our Centrifugal Compression business and our net proceeds after taxes are estimated to be $600 million. As a result of the sale, we will recognize that estimated gain for financial segment purposes of approximately $400 [ph] million, which will be reflected in discontinued ops in Q1.
We purchased 3.4 million shares of our stock during the quarter and we ended the year with $476 million of availability under our authorization. The strength of our balance sheet puts us in a position to take advantage of opportunities as they arise during the course of this downcycle, whether they be through organic investments in our business, acquisitions or just on share repurchases.
Now turning to the 2015 outlook. We are confident in our ability to execute our backlog. $5.7 billion of which is scheduled to ship out in '15. However, our shorter cycle businesses, which generated $4.4 billion of revenues in '14 will be challenged by the current market conditions. Our customers are continuing to adjust their spending plans, which has clouded our ability to predict what the level of shorter cycle revenue will be in '15.
As a result, we do not believe we can provide you accurate guidance regarding earnings per share given the uncertainty around our shorter-cycle businesses and that explains why we were discussing our segments in more detail. We do believe that our new segment presentation we aid investors in thinking about the range of possible earnings Cameron may generate in this uncertain market.
To help you think through each of our segments, I'll cover some important points. Our Subsea segment has significant portion of its 2015 revenues and backlog. In fact, $2.1 billion of its backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. To help you think about how Subsea shorter cycles businesses may affect its 2015 revenue, 2014 fell approximately $800 million of such revenue, which primarily represents services. These services typically do not experience as much contraction in a downmarket as does our Surface segment. Therefore, we see a lot less revenue risks in this segment.
Given our focus on backlog and margins ver the past several years, our Surface Subsea segment should see margin expansion in 2015 when compared to the full year '14 margin of 6.7, however, it will come down from the fourth quarter level of 10%.
With the success of our CAM Shell initiatives over the last 4 years, our Surface segment has become heavier weighted towards a more service-intensive North American market. Therefore the current market correction will have a pronounced impact on the North American portion of this segment. However, the international portion, which comprises half of Surface, will be more insulated from the current microenvironment.
A few data points: Approximately $750 million of Surface's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, Surface had approximately $1.7 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, which will be impact by the reduced activity levels. While our customers are typically the more longer-term focused customers, Surface will not be immune from the reduced activity levels nor the pricing pressures, which are being experienced in North America. Surface's shorter-cycle businesses are somewhat protected from the full blunt of the reduced activity level due to value proposition we deliver to our customers, however, it will certainly see downward pressure on its operating margin in '15.
Drilling has approximately $2 billion of its backlog, which will ship in '15. In 2014, Drilling had approximately $800 million of shorter-cycle businesses, which is centered around our Surface and land BLD markets. Therefore, this portion of this business will be impacted by the downcycle. However, continued improvement and internal efficiency could allow us to grow Drilling's 2015 operating margin slightly from '14 level of 15.5%, depending on the ultimate level of pricing pressure we experience. Approximately $850 million of V&M backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, V&M had approximately $1.2 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, a significant amount of which was focused on North America activity. V&M is different than Surfaces and North American businesses, and that's a significant portion of V&M North American business goes through distributors. 
During cyclical downturns, V&M experiences a painful destocking process, whereby this are bidders bleed off existing inventories before ordering new inventory. Therefore, the downturn will have a more is significant impact on V&M's revenue when compared to Surfaces, which revenue decline will put significant downward pressure on V&M's operating margin percent.
Now a few overall comments for Cameron. Cameron's consolidated operating margin, which includes corporate expenses but excludes interests and other costs, contracted 170 basis points during the '08 downturn. While the company isn't much different today than it was during the 2008 time period, we will certainly see a contraction still in our 2015 overall consolidated margin.
At this time, however, we see that contraction being somewhat less than the 170 basis points I mentioned.
A few other 2015 items. Interest expense should approximate $140 million. [indiscernible] segment revenues to be about $160 million and the corresponding amount of margin to eliminate on these sales is $35 million. Our tax rate, 23%. Our CapEx will come down to approximately 300  to 350, while focused on majority focus on revenue-generating assets. Corporate expenses to approximate $130 million and interest should be about $140 million.
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was Deepwater costs that started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought and a lot of that was customers pulling back to the costs. So the effort to look more standard solutions. And we talked about standard solutions, it's not reinventing the wheel on welding specs and metallurgies and it's using things that we have all developed in the course of developing prior projects that are proving to be very, very robust and fit for purpose and the scope of environment that they're working in. So it's really getting people back to ground and back to things that we've already done. So you can actually catch up time and reduce time by doing this. So some of these projects that have been recalibrated for the last 6 months, we could see those cycle out here fairly sooner than later in 2015.

componenttext: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environment where, at least where we're going to be maybe constrained on hydrocarbon price over the next several years. But I think you really have to go look at this instead of huge Deepwater developments. So we're working with a lot of operators to go in existing and older fields where infrastructure's there, utilize some of our Subsea processing technologies and some of the advances we're making and do a list and list systems to help change the economics of those opportunities. And we think that's going to create an incremental opportunity for the OneSubsea platform way into the future.

componenttext: Well, first, we've got a great balance sheet. It's unbelievably well positioned for this downturn, so we're very comfortable there. I think we're going to have opportunities to invest organically in our business to take advantage of some dislocations that occur. Depending on the depth and length of this downcycle, people are going to get themselves in trouble. componenttextpreview: Yes. Brad, right now every customer's asking for some degree of pricing release and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle this that our overall pricing will be something far less than that and how we have to ma
componenttext: Yes. Brad, right now every customer's asking for some degree of pricing release and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle this that our overall pricing will be something far less than that and how we have to manage that is a number of fronts, right. First of all come its internal costs and making sure that we can all sit anything we do internally through just more efficient activities in ourselves or more through our own supply chain network. The other is really working with customers to broaden our share of their footprint where we can defer some of that costs across more volume and that is something we were successful doing the last cycle. And also given the relationships we have with customers today, most of them are focused not only on costs but efficiency and how can they be more efficient at the well side, consumed less product or consume last time and we even have that's we've got a great platform to work with them especially on the Surface systems where we have the most efficient Surface wellhead systems literarily in the world. And we've been able to prove that with customers. So we will leverage that to -- versus just roll over and concede pricing. And -- but it won't be as bad as what we are being asked to do but I do think it will be able to offset a lot of our price discounting through more efficiencies internally. But we will not be able to scape it totally.

componenttextpreview: So today, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spending the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects m
componenttext: So today, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spending the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects much more efficient in taking time and people out of the equation. And so typically on a large project, right, from that time your awarded the design user to deliver equipment is anywhere from a 2 -- you start to deliver equipment after year 1 into year 2 and year 3. And so what we're trying to do on a standardization effort and some of the other things that we're doing within OneSubsea is really trying to shorten that cycle from time of order to time of equipment. And what we're doing is standardizing the shale specifications or standardized quality plans, we're standardizing welding specifications. And by doing that, we taking out a lot of people, we're taking out a lot of time. And anytime you can reduce that cycle time, you're driving pretty significant cost out of the equation. So we've been doing this now for about 3 years. We're having some very significant wins with some of our operators and partners and I also really think that the overall costs will come down in a pretty significant magnitude as operators start to break some of the dynamics and possibly some of the bad habits that they are doing historically when developing these yields.

componenttext: You're exactly right. Gas does drive a lot of that activity in parts of the world. Middle East is -- has been a very strong active market for us in over the last several years. We'll see it be a healthy market this year, although we expect to see some parts of the Middle East be impacted more than others. But also the Far East. We've got good presence there and a lot of markets there and especially international oil companies that we're working with there are still very committed in terms of ensuring their energy supply sources or not compromised through the downturn by continuing to invest in the infrastructure. So those markets have been very constructive for us. North Sea, we saw it decline last year and we really haven't seen it stop declining. So I think you're going to continue to see the North see cycle down relative to where we were in this past year.

It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Lamb, Vice President, Investor Relations for Cameron. Thank you, Mr. Lamb, you may begin.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; and Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and C
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; and Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's Annual Report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of our Drilling and Surface segments along with a significant reduction in the company's overhead expense. Most notably, our Drilling segment reported a 89% increase in operating income and an almost 700 basis point improvement in margin relative to the year-ago quarter, while the Surface business reported a 23% increase in operating income. 
Consolidated SG&A expense declined 11% relative to the year-ago quarter. On a consolidated basis, these factors contributed to an operating income margin of 15% for Cameron. Additionally, the company generated $938 million of cash from operations during the quarter, an increase of 49% compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 and reflected in part our sharpened focus on reducing working capital.
Overall, 2014 was a great year for Cameron on a number of fronts. Most impressive was the turnaround story with our Drilling Systems. As previously mentioned, we saw a 700 basis point improvement in margins versus year-ago levels. Even more importantly, we have now embedded both processes and work practices that have driven predictable success in executing our backlog.
We are also very pleased with the timing and the outcome of the divestiture process with compression. Not only did we generate $1.5 billion of sales proceeds, it also allowed us to sharpen our focus on Cameron's core oil and gas businesses. We implemented a number of cost reduction programs that began the process to streamline our support structure across all of our business units, which proved to be meaningful contributor to improving overall margins. 
We returned $1.7 billion of cash to shareholders in 2014, while maintaining a very healthy balance sheet. And the momentum we created with investing and broadening the platform of our core businesses will benefit us in a market where customers' attention turns cost and efficiency versus just availability.
Now some comments regarding outlook for 2015, and I will start with our onshore markets. Clearly, we are witnessing a very sharp correction in activity that will negatively impact our Surface, Valves and Drilling segments in 2015. North America will be impacted much harder than international. The degree to which North America activity correct is still unknown. The range of possibilities will be heavily influenced by both the customer and the basin. 
Cameron has a broad presence in North America and we have a very broad customer base. Mostly populated with IOCs, major independents and the major drilling contractors, all of which we se as a positive to have in this environment. Cameron also has a very large international onshore presence which will contract at a slower rate, and in some markets could even expand. Cameron's customer base is made up mostly of large IOCs and NOCs whose attitudes towards investing through cycles have proven to be more predictable. 
As for our offshore in deepwater markets, OneSubsea, Drilling Systems and Valve markets will all be exposed to the pullback in spending we are witnessing, offshore as well. We saw the pause button hit on most deepwater drilling capital spending last year and nothing in our view has changed with the exception that we are not seeing drilling contractors actually scrap older generation rigs. Something we have rarely seen in prior year cycles which, in time, is a positive for some form of newbuild recovery. We will seek some compression in the services part of our businesses due to the lower utilization and pricing, but we also see opportunity to serve a broader portfolio of products from our rig equipment acquisitions. 
As for Subsea projects, most every perspective project we are tracking has or is going through a recalibration process for both scope and price. Some of this work actually started last year. While we fully expect to see projects award in 2015, the value or result of these exercises maybe different from what we were thinking 6 months ago. The importance of deepwater projects in our customers' portfolios have not changed. The timing on which one cycle to the forefront and the current cost environment will, which I'll place to the strengths that OneSubsea was created to deliver.
Having said all of that, I'll remind you that Cameron has a substantial backlog of work. And that backlog provides us with good visibility into a portion of our 2015 operating revenues and margins. And our confidence to deliver that backlog at the margins and in the time frame we have in our plan is very high, given the performance we've seen throughout 2014.
However, we will see our equally, if not more important, shorter cycle booked and built businesses meaningfully impacted by the current environment. And the speed in which we have seen the correction in this cycle over the past months has created significant uncertainty with the degree that this will impact both the revenues and margins of our short-cycle businesses, especially those in North America.
Given we're still very early in the cycle, it would be challenging to predict the range of outcomes within our budget and therefore, feel it's prudent not providing annual EPS guidance for 2015. Chuck will, however, provide detailed commentary on each of our operating segments.
While trying to speculate on the depth and duration of this cycle, corrections will be difficult. Rest assured that Cameron will stay very close to our customers to ensure we are advancing and investing the most cost efficient solutions for their operations, not compromise on our commitment to service and execution excellence, aggressively manage our call structure to the reality of the business and be opportunistic towards expanding our core platforms. You can also expect us to leverage our broad product, customer and geographic diversity to expand share. Every operator is currently reviewing their supplier's performance to ensure that they have the most cost-effective partner in this environment, and that will open doors for Cameron. This competitive drive will help us weather this cycle, as we have weathered previous cycles, and emerge as an even more formidable company over the longer term.
I will now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structur
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structure down every quarter in 2014 while performing at this record activity rate. The focus on execution, cost reduction and servicing our customers results in strong margin progression throughout the year. The fourth quarter results were a culmination of a lot of hard work and diligence that positions the enterprise in a better place to perform on the challenges that we face in 2015.
Now let's switch gears to the present, in 2015. The weak macro environment, as Jack described, is certainly evident when you look at Cameron's orders and backlog position in the fourth quarter of 2014. Our book-to-bill ratio in the quarter was 0.7:1, as order intake declined in all of our businesses on a sequential quarter basis. There were, however, a couple of bright spots of customer activity during the fourth quarter. In particular, we booked a multiyear contract with ExxonMobil for topside wellhead equipment and production trees for the Hebron project, a 52-well development located offshore Newfoundland, as well as OneSubsea's execution of a Subsea well-intervention alliance with Helix and Schlumberger. 
Nevertheless, the order flow was weak and the net result of that was a decline in our backlog to roughly $9.5 billion at the end of the quarter. Despite the reduction in backlog, the backlog itself is substantial, especially in our longer cycle businesses, OneSubsea and Drilling. The organization is highly focused on our ability to execute our backlog and the operational improvements realized in 2014 will carry over into 2015.
As Jack said, in this challenging macro environment, Cameron is absolutely focused on the things they can control. We are committed to our objective of delivering steady improvement in our consolidated operating margins, on average, over time. To be clear, over a multiyear period, some of these improvement could be temporarily masked by pricing pressure and reduced volumes, but we are confident in our ability to keep advancing this program over the long term and driving excellence in our ability to execute.
We are seeking to do this through continuous improvements in virtually every aspect of our operations from our supply chain to product delivery and throughout our corporate and support services organizations. We are finding ways to work smarter, faster and more efficiently and more creatively interesting we do. 
We also want to ensure that we're operating at maximum cost effectiveness. The cost reduction steps that were taken in 2014 are helping us prepare for 2015. We will, and have already taken further cost reductions in the first quarter, and we will continue to aggressively drive our cost structure down throughout the year as we work off the backlog.
In addition to volume reduction, the other challenge we are facing is pricing. The majority of our customers are seeking or have already asked for price concessions to help them weather the current environment. And Cameron's response to this request has been a proactive and collaborative approach. We are working with our customers to provide improved technology in processes, while we reduce their overall spending commitments and their operating costs. We feel that the largest cost savings for operators will come from a drive towards standardization, improved technology and further customer integration. We are in the early days but we are already seeing a few wins with this approach.
Each of our businesses will have different drivers and behave differently throughout the downcycle. Having completed our divestiture program in 2014, we are committed to each of our 4 operating segments, and I'm confident that we will emerge through this cycle better than ever. OneSubsea will continue to build on the quarter process approach that will help operators improve their overall recovery in their deepwater developments. We continue to progress in this endeavor and operators will need help finding cost effective solutions to generate higher production from their deepwater assets.
Our Surface division is well positioned as the market leader to continue to outperform in a relative basis and grow market share by providing the highest service level and the best reliability in the industry. In Drilling, we will take this opportunity in the downturn to complete a comprehensive and integrated drilling offering. Our Valves & Measurement segment touches everything we do in Cameron in every segment of our businesses. We will leverage the breadth and knowledge within the enterprise to ensure that Valves & Measurement outperforms in this business cycle.
While we're actively and realistically facing the current market situation, Cameron is poised to take advantage of the opportunities that will present themselves. We're being proactive in our approach to manage our customers and our cost structure. We have a highly engaged team and we have a relentless drive towards excellence. The activities and programs that we're implementing now will position Cameron for a long-term success and outperformance throughout the cycle. 
I'll now turn it over to Chuck for the financials.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts our models. Revenues for the quarter wer
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts our models. 
Revenues for the quarter were $2.8 billion, a 5% increase sequentially. Segment operating income margins were 15% for the quarter, flat sequentially but up 200 basis points from prior year level. Corporate expenses for the quarter were $35 million and EPS before other costs was a $1.34, an all-time quarterly record.
The key message in our fourth quarter financials is the operating margin improvement we've made throughout 2014. The improvements have come from better efficiency in our plants, as well as tight control over our costs, and these will serve us well during the downturn.
Subsea revenues increased 12% sequentially, whilst operating margin improved to 10%, reflecting the strength of our margin and backlog. We are pleased with the sequential progression that recognize the need to continue to grow our services offering in this segment to further enhance margins.
Our Surface revenues increased 10% sequentially and represented the highest revenue level in our history, driven primarily by North America. This operating margin improved 110 basis points sequentially, driven by the higher revenue level as well as improved mix in North America.
Drilling revenues increased 2% sequentially. To give you some perspective on the improvements Drilling has made over the last 12 months, the fourth quarter revenue is 20% higher than it was in the year-ago period. Operating margin for Drilling was 18.5%, which is below the previous quarter simply due to mix. The fourth quarter operating margin is 850 basis points higher than the low point we saw in Q1 of this year.
V&M revenues decreased 5% sequentially as it has struggled with orders and pricing in its engineered valve lines all year. As a result, we were hit hard this quarter with absorption challenges and lower margin engineered valve shipments, which resulted in a decline in Q4 operating margin to 15.3%. We're in the midst of completing a realignment of this segment, which will allow us to capture additional market share while lowering our costs at the same time.
Cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter was $938 million, obviously, a record level as our working capital efficiency drive begins to show results. As a result, we ended the year with $1.6 billion of cash and short-term investments. As we announced earlier in the month, we completed our sale of our Centrifugal Compression business. And our net proceeds, after taxes, are estimated to be $600 million. As a result of the sale, we will recognize that estimated gain, for financial statement purposes, of approximately $400 million, which will be reflected in discontinued ops in Q1.
We purchased 3.4 million shares of our stock during the quarter, and we ended the year with $476 million of availability under our authorization. The strength of our balance sheet puts us in the position to take advantage of opportunities as they arise during the course of this downcycle. Whether they be through organic investments in our business, acquisitions or just on share repurchases.
Now turning to the 2015 outlook. We are confident in our ability to execute our backlog, $5.7 billion of which is scheduled to ship out in '15. However, our shorter cycle businesses, which generated $4.4 billion of revenues in '14, will be challenged by the current market conditions. Our customers are continuing to adjust their spending plans, which has clouded our ability to predict what the level of shorter cycle revenue will be in '15.
As a result, we do not believe we can provide you accurate guidance regarding earnings per share given the uncertainty around our shorter-cycle businesses, and that explains why we're discussing our segments in more detail. We do believe that our new segment presentation will aid investors in thinking about the range of possible earnings Cameron may generate in this uncertain market.
To help you think through each of our segments, I'll cover some important points. Our Subsea segment has significant portion of its 2015 revenues and backlog. In fact, $2.1 billion of its backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. To help you think about how Subsea shorter cycles businesses may affect its 2015 revenue, 2014 saw approximately $800 million of such revenue, which primarily represents services. These services typically do not experience as much contraction in a downmarket as does our Surface segment. Therefore, we see a lot less revenue risks in this segment. Given our focus on backlog and margins over the past several years, our Subsea segment should see margin expansion in 2015 when compared to the full year '14 margin of 6.7. However, it will come down from the fourth quarter level of 10%.
With the success of our CAM Shell initiative over the last 4 years, our Surface segment has become heavier weighted towards a more service-intensive North American market. Therefore the current market correction will have a pronounced impact on the North American portion of this segment. However, the international portion, which comprises half of Surface, will be more insulated from the current microenvironment.
A few data points: Approximately $750 million of Surface's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, Surface had approximately $1.7 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, which will be impacted by the reduced activity levels. While our customers are typically the more longer-term focused customers, Surface will not be immune from the reduced activity levels nor the pricing pressures which are being experienced in North America. Surface's shorter-cycle business is somewhat protected from the full blunt of the reduced activity level due to value proposition we deliver to our customers. However, it will certainly see downward pressure on its operating margin in '15.
Drilling has approximately $2 billion of its backlog which will ship in '15. In 2014, Drilling had approximately $800 million of shorter-cycle businesses which is centered around our services and land BOP markets. Therefore, this portion of this business will be impacted by the downcycle. However, continued improvement in internal efficiency could allow us to grow Drilling's 2015 operating margin slightly from '14's level of 15.5%, depending on the ultimate level of pricing pressure we experience. 
Approximately $850 million of V&M's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, V&M had approximately $1.2 billion of shorter-cycle businesses. A significant amount of which was focused on North America activity. V&M is different than Surfaces' North American business, and that a significant portion of V&M North American business goes through distributors. 
During cyclical downturns, V&M experiences a painful destocking process, whereby distributors bleed off existing inventories before ordering new inventory. Therefore, the downturn will have a more is significant impact on V&M's revenue when compared to Surfaces. This revenue decline will put significant downward pressure on V&M's operating margin percent.
Now a few overall comments for Cameron. Cameron's consolidated operating margin, which includes corporate expenses but excludes interests and other costs, contracted 170 basis points during the '08 downturn. While the company is much different today than it was during the 2008 time period, we will certainly see a contraction still in our 2015 overall consolidated margin. At this time, however, we see that contraction being somewhat less than the 170 basis points I mentioned.
A few other 2015 items. Interest expense should approximate $140 million. Interest -- segment revenue should be about $160 million and the corresponding amount of margin to eliminate on these sales is $35 million. Our tax rate, 23%. Our CapEx will come down to approximately 300 to 350, all focused on -- or majority focus on revenue-generating assets. Corporate expenses should approximate $130 million and interest should be about $140 million.
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was deepwater costs that started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought and a lot of that was customers pulling back to the costs. So the effort to look more at standard solutions. And when we talked about standard solutions, it's not reinventing the wheel on welding specs and metallurgies and -- it's using things that we have all developed in the course of developing prior projects that are proven to be very, very robust and fit for purpose and the scope of the environment that they're working in. So it's really getting people back to ground and back to things that we've already done. So you can actually catch up time and reduce time by doing this. So some of these projects that have been recalibrated for the last 6 months, we could see those cycle out here fairly sooner than later in 2015.

componenttext: I wouldn't say that anyone is talking about newbuilds at this stage of where we're at. componenttext: Yes. So that -- you're right, Bill. The challenge there is how much price do we get and how much pressure do we get and how much can we leverage our supply chain to offset that. componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, a more conceptual question with regard to Deepwater and Subsea in general. I hear you with regard to the reworking of project economics standardization and what have you. But I think one of the things that is troubling for Deepwater coming out of this cycle, which we will eventually do so relative to 2009. Is that the prospectivity of Deepwater looks diminished and the discoveries over the past 2 years, whether they prove to be transient or structural, but certainly are -- have been incredibly disappointing. And so how do you guys think about the Deepwater growth narrative coming out of this catharsis relative to where we were in 2009?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environm
componenttext: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environment where, and at least where we're going to be, maybe constrained on a hydrocarbon price over the next several years. But I think you really have to go look at this instead of huge deepwater developments. We see a lot of opportunities with going in and creating new cheese, as they say, around existing environments and to step out and so forth that are already in place. So we're working with a lot of operators to go in the existing and older fields where infrastructure is there, utilize some of our Subsea processing technologies and some of the advances we're making in dual lift and lift systems to help change the economics of those opportunities. And we think that's going to create an incremental opportunity for the OneSubsea platform way into the future.

componenttext: Well, first, we've got a great balance sheet. It's unbelievably well positioned for this downturn, so we're very comfortable there. I think we're going to have opportunities to invest organically in our business to take advantage of some dislocations that occur. Depending on the depth and length of this downcycle, people are going to get themselves in trouble. And you have seen in past downcycles, Cameron take advantage of that through combinations or acquisitions of assets that make sense for us to our own. And during this cycle, we've got authorization left and we would expect to continue buying some shares. I think it's going to be a combination of all those, but we are also very mindful that this is a downcycle and we are watching things carefully. We've got a phenomenal focus on pulling working capital out of this business as these contraction occurs. So I think we'll have a good cash flow year. We're going to make sure we do the right things with that cash and position ourselves even better when we come out of this.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brad, right now every customer is asking for some degree of pricing relief and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle this that our overall pricing relief will be something far less than that. And how we ha
componenttext: Yes. Brad, right now every customer is asking for some degree of pricing relief and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle this that our overall pricing relief will be something far less than that. And how we have to manage that is in a number of fronts, right? First of all there's internal costs and making sure that we can offset anything we do internally through just more efficient activities on ourselves or more through our own supply chain network. The other is really working with customers to broaden our share of their footprint where we can defer some of that costs across more volume. And that is something we were successful doing the last cycle. And I tell you with the relationships we have with customers today, most of them are focused not only on costs but efficiency. How can they be more efficient at the well site, consume less product or consume less time. And we have -- we've got a great platform to work with them on that, especially on the Surface systems where we have the most efficient Surface wellhead system, literarily, in the world. And we've been able to prove that with a lot of customers. So we will leverage that to -- versus just roll over and concede pricing. And -- but it won't be as bad as what we are being asked to do, but I do think that we'll be able to offset a lot of our price discounting through more efficiencies internally. But we will not be able to escape it totally.

componenttextpreview: So Dave, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spending I the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects
componenttext: So Dave, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spending I the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects much more efficient in taking time and people out of the equation. And so typically on a large project, right, from the time you award to the time you start to deliver equipment is anywhere from a 2 -- you start to deliver equipment after year 1 into year 2 and year 3. And so what we're trying to do on our standardization effort and some of the other things that we're doing within OneSubsea is really try to shorten that cycle from time of order to time of equipment. And what we're doing is standardizing material specifications, we're standardizing quality plans, we're standardizing welding specifications. And by doing that, we're taking out a lot of people, we're taking out a lot of time. And anytime you can reduce that cycle time, you're driving pretty significant cost out of the equation. So we've been doing this now for about 3 years. We're having some very significant wins with some of our operators and partners. And I also really think that the overall costs will come down in a pretty significant magnitude as operators start to break some of the dynamics and possibly some of the bad habits that they are doing historically when developing these fields.

Greetings, and welcome to the Cameron Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Lamb, Vice President, Investor Relations for Cameron. Thank you, Mr. Lamb, you may begin.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
