componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's Annual Report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of o
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of our Drilling and Surface segments, along with a significant reduction in the company's overhead expense. Most notably, our Drilling segment reported a 89% increase in operating income and an almost 700-basis-point improvement in margin relative to the year-ago quarter, while the Surface business reported a 23% increase in operating income. 
Consolidated SG&A expense declined 11% relative to the year-ago quarter. On a consolidated basis, these factors contributed to an operating income margin of 15% for Cameron. Additionally, the company generated $938 million of cash from operations during the quarter, an increase of 49% compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 and reflected, in part, our sharpened focus on reducing working capital.
Overall, 2014 was a great year for Cameron on a number of fronts. Most impressive was the turnaround story with our Drilling Systems. As previously mentioned, we saw a 700-basis-point improvement in margins versus year-ago levels. Even more importantly, we have now embedded both processes and work practices that have driven predictable success in executing our backlog.
We are also very pleased with the timing and the outcome of the divestiture process with compression. Not only did we generate $1.5 billion of sales proceeds, it also allowed us to sharpen our focus on Cameron's core oil and gas businesses. We implemented a number of cost reduction programs that began the process to streamline our support structure across all of our business units, which proved to be a meaningful contributor to improving overall margins. 
We returned $1.7 billion of cash to shareholders in 2014, while maintaining a very healthy balance sheet. And the momentum we created with investing and broadening the platform of our core businesses will benefit us in a market where customers' attention turns cost and efficiency versus just availability.
Now some comments regarding our outlook for 2015, and I will start with our onshore markets. Clearly, we are witnessing a very sharp correction in activity that will negatively impact our Surface, Valves and Drilling segments in 2015. North America will be impacted much harder than international. The degree to which North America activity will correct is still unknown. The range of possibilities will be heavily influenced by both the customer and the basin. 
Cameron has a broad presence in North America and we have a very broad customer base, mostly populated with IOCs, major independents and the major drilling contractors, all of which we see as a positive to have in this environment. Cameron also has a very large international onshore presence which will contract at a slower rate and in some markets could even expand. Cameron's customer base is made up mostly of large IOCs and NOCs whose attitudes towards investing through cycles have proven to be more predictable. 
As for our offshore and deepwater markets, OneSubsea, Drilling Systems and Valve markets will all be exposed to the pullback in spending we are witnessing, offshore as well. We saw the pause button hit on most deepwater drilling capital spending last year and nothing in our view has changed, with the exception that we are not seeing drilling contractors actually scrap older generation rigs. Something we have rarely seen in prior year cycles which, in time, is a positive for some form of newbuild recovery. We will seek some compression in the services part of our businesses due to the lower utilization and pricing, but we also see opportunity to serve a broader portfolio of products from our rig equipment acquisitions. 
As for Subsea projects, most every perspective project we are tracking has or is going through a recalibration process for both scope and price. Some of this work actually started last year. While we fully expect to see projects awarded in 2015, the value or result of these exercises may be different from what we were thinking 6 months ago. The importance of deepwater projects in our customers' portfolios has not changed. The timing on which one cycle to the forefront and the current cost environment will, which all plays to the strengths that OneSubsea was created to deliver.
Having said all of that, I'll remind you that Cameron has a substantial backlog of work. And that backlog provides us with good visibility into a portion of our 2015 operating revenues and margins. And our confidence to deliver that backlog at the margins and in the time frame we have in our plan is very high, given the performance we've seen throughout 2014.
However, we will see our equally, if not more important, shorter-cycle book and bill businesses meaningfully impacted by the current environment. And the speed in which we have seen the correction in this cycle over the past months has created significant uncertainty with the degree that this will impact both the revenues and margins of our short-cycle businesses, especially those in North America.
Given we're still very early in the cycle, it would be challenging to predict the range of outcomes within our budget and, therefore, feel it's prudent not providing annual EPS guidance for 2015. Chuck will, however, provide detailed commentary on each of our operating segments.
While trying to speculate on the depth and duration of this cycle, corrections will be difficult. Rest assured that Cameron will stay very close to our customers to ensure we are advancing and investing the most cost-efficient solutions for their operations, not compromise on our commitment to service and execution excellence, aggressively manage our cost structure to the reality of the business and be opportunistic towards expanding our core platforms. You can also expect us to leverage our broad product, customer and geographic diversity to expand share. Every operator is currently reviewing their supplier's performance to ensure that they have the most cost-effective partner in this environment, and that will open doors for Cameron. This competitive drive will help us weather this cycle, as we have weathered previous cycles, and emerge as an even more formidable company over the longer term.
I will now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever, while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structu
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever, while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structure down every quarter in 2014 while performing at this record activity rate. The focus on execution, cost reduction and servicing our customers results in strong margin progression throughout the year. The fourth quarter results were a culmination of a lot of hard work and diligence that positions the enterprise in a better place to perform on the challenges that we face in 2015.
Now let's switch gears to the present, in 2015. The weak macro environment that Jack described is certainly evident when you look at Cameron's orders and backlog position in the fourth quarter of 2014. Our book-to-bill ratio in the quarter was 0.7:1, as order intake declined in all of our businesses on a sequential quarter basis. There were, however, a couple of bright spots of customer activity during the fourth quarter. In particular, we booked a multiyear contract with ExxonMobil for topside wellhead equipment and production trees for the Hebron project, a 52-well development located offshore Newfoundland, as well as OneSubsea's execution of a Subsea well-intervention alliance with Helix and Schlumberger. 
Nevertheless, the order flow was weak and the net result of that was a decline in our backlog to roughly $9.5 billion at the end of the quarter. Despite the reduction in backlog, the backlog itself is substantial, especially in our longer-cycle businesses, OneSubsea and Drilling. The organization is highly focused on our ability to execute our backlog and the operational improvements realized in 2014 will carry over into 2015.
As Jack said, in this challenging macro environment, Cameron is absolutely focused on the things they can control. We are committed to our objective of delivering steady improvement in our consolidated operating margins, on average, over time. To be clear, over a multiyear period, some of this improvement could be temporarily masked by pricing pressure and reduced volumes, but we are confident in our ability to keep advancing this program over the long term and driving excellence in our ability to execute.
We are seeking to do this through continuous improvements in virtually every aspect of our operations, from our supply chain to product delivery, and throughout our corporate and support services organizations. We are finding ways to work smarter, faster and more efficiently and more creatively in everything we do. 
We also want to ensure that we're operating at maximum cost effectiveness. The cost-reduction steps that were taken in 2014 are helping us prepare for 2015. We will and have already taken further cost reductions in the first quarter, and we will continue to aggressively drive our cost structure down throughout the year as we work off the existing backlog.
In addition to volume reduction, the other challenge we are facing is pricing. The majority of our customers are seeking or have already asked for price concessions to help them weather the current environment. The Cameron response to this request has been a proactive and collaborative approach. We are working with our customers to provide improved technology in processes that will reduce their overall spending commitments and their operating costs. We feel that the largest cost savings for operators will come from a drive towards standardization, improved technology and further customer integration. We are in the early days, but we are already seeing a few wins with this approach.
Each of our businesses will have different drivers and behave differently throughout the downcycle. Having completed our divestiture program in 2014, we are committed to each of our 4 operating segments, and I am confident that we will emerge through this cycle better than ever. OneSubsea will continue to build on the Pore to Process approach that will help operators improve their overall recovery in their deepwater developments. We continue to progress in this endeavor and operators will need help finding cost-effective solutions that generate higher production from their deepwater assets.
Our Surface division is well positioned as the market leader to continue to outperform on a relative basis and grow market share by providing the highest service level and the best reliability in the industry. In Drilling, we will take this opportunity in the downturn to complete a comprehensive and integrated drilling offering. Our Valves & Measurement segment touches everything we do in Cameron in every segment of our businesses. We will leverage the breadth and knowledge within the enterprise to ensure that Valves & Measurement outperforms in this business cycle.
While we are actively and realistically facing the current market situation, Cameron is poised to take advantage of the opportunities that will present themselves. We're being proactive in our approach to manage our customers and our cost structure. We have a highly engaged team and we have a relentless drive towards excellence. The activities and programs that we are implementing now will position Cameron for a long-term success and outperformance throughout the cycle. 
I'll now turn it over to Chuck for the financials.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts their models. Revenues for the quarter w
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts their models. 
Revenues for the quarter were $2.8 billion, a 5% increase sequentially. Segment operating income margins were 15% for the quarter, flat sequentially but up 200 basis points from prior year level. Corporate expenses for the quarter were $35 million and EPS before other costs was a $1.34, an all-time quarterly record.
The key message in our fourth quarter financials is the operating margin improvement we've made throughout 2014. The improvements have come from better efficiency in our plants, as well as tight control over our costs, and these will serve us well during the downturn.
Subsea revenues increased 12% sequentially, while its operating margin improved to 10%, reflecting the strength of our margin and backlog. We are pleased with the sequential progression and recognize the need to continue to grow our services offering in this segment to further enhance margins.
Our Surface revenues increased 10% sequentially and represented the highest revenue level in our history, driven primarily by North America. This operating margin improved 110 basis points sequentially, driven by the higher revenue level as well as improved mix in North America.
Drilling's revenues increased 2% sequentially. To give you some perspective on the improvements Drilling has made over the last 12 months, the fourth quarter revenue is 20% higher than it was in the year-ago period. Operating margin for Drilling was 18.5%, which is below the previous quarter simply due to mix. The fourth quarter operating margin is 850 basis points higher than the low point we saw in Q1 of this year.
V&M revenues decreased 5% sequentially, as it has struggled with orders and pricing in its engineered valve lines all year. As a result, we were hit hard this quarter with absorption challenges and lower-margin engineered valve shipments, which resulted in a decline in Q4 operating margin to 15.3%. We're in the midst of completing a realignment of this segment, which will allow us to capture additional market share while lowering our costs at the same time.
Cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter was $938 million, obviously, a record level, as our working capital efficiency drive begins to show results. As a result, we ended the year with $1.6 billion of cash and short-term investments. As we announced earlier in the month, we completed our sale of our Centrifugal Compression business. And our net proceeds, after taxes, are estimated to be $600 million. As a result of the sale, we will recognize that estimated gain, for financial statement purposes, of approximately $400 million, which will be reflected in discontinued ops in Q1.
We purchased 3.4 million shares of our stock during the quarter, and we ended the year with $476 million of availability under our authorization. The strength of our balance sheet puts us in the position to take advantage of opportunities as they arise during the course of this downcycle. Whether they be through organic investments in our business, acquisitions or just in share repurchases.
Now turning to the 2015 outlook. We are confident in our ability to execute our backlog, $5.7 billion of which is scheduled to ship out in '15. However, our shorter-cycle businesses, which generated $4.4 billion of revenues in '14, will be challenged by the current market conditions. Our customers are continuing to adjust their spending plans, which has clouded our ability to predict what the level of shorter-cycle revenue will be in '15.
As a result, we do not believe we can provide you accurate guidance regarding earnings per share given the uncertainty around our shorter-cycle businesses, and that explains why we're discussing our segments in more detail. We do believe that our new segment presentation will aid investors in thinking about the range of possible earnings Cameron may generate in this uncertain market.
To help you think through each of our segments, I'll cover some important points. Our Subsea segment has a significant portion of its 2015 revenues and backlog. In fact, $2.1 billion of its backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. To help you think about how Subsea shorter-cycles businesses may affect its 2015 revenue, 2014 saw approximately $800 million of such revenue, which primarily represents services. These services typically do not experience as much contraction in a downmarket as does our Surface segment. Therefore, we see a lot less revenue risks in this segment. Given our focus on backlog margins over the past several years, our Subsea segment should see margin expansion in 2015 when compared to the full year '14 margin of 6.7. However, it will come down from the fourth quarter level of 10%.
With the success of our CAM Shell initiative over the last 4 years, our Surface segment has become heavier weighted towards a more service-intensive North American market. Therefore, the current market correction will have a pronounced impact on the North American portion of this segment. However, the international portion, which comprises half of Surface, will be more insulated from the current macro environment.
A few data points: Approximately $750 million of Surface's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, Surface had approximately $1.7 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, which will be impacted by the reduced activity levels. While our customers are typically the more longer-term-focused customers, Surface will not be immune from the reduced activity levels nor the pricing pressures which are being experienced in North America. Surface's shorter-cycle business is somewhat protected from the full blunt of the reduced activity level due to the value proposition we deliver to our customers. However, it will certainly see downward pressure on its operating margin in '15.
Drilling has approximately $2 billion of its backlog which will ship in '15. In 2014, Drilling had approximately $800 million of shorter-cycle businesses, which is centered around our services and land BOP markets. Therefore, this portion of the business will be impacted by the downcycle. However, continued improvement in internal efficiency could allow us to grow Drilling's 2015 operating margin slightly from '14's level of 15.5%, depending on the ultimate level of pricing pressure we experience. 
Approximately $850 million of V&M's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, V&M had approximately $1.2 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, a significant amount of which was focused on North America activity. V&M is different than Surfaces' North American business, and that a significant portion of V&M North American business goes through distributors. 
During cyclical downturns, V&M experiences a painful destocking process, whereby distributors bleed off existing inventories before ordering new inventory. Therefore, the downturn will have a more significant impact on V&M's revenue when compared to Surfaces. This revenue decline will put significant downward pressure on V&M's operating margin percent.
Now a few overall comments for Cameron. Cameron's consolidated operating margin, which includes corporate expenses but excludes interests and other costs, contracted 170 basis points during the '08 downturn. While the company is much different today than it was during the 2008 time period, we will certainly see a contraction still in our 2015 overall consolidated margin. At this time, however, we see that contraction being somewhat less than the 170 basis points I mentioned.
A few other 2015 items. Interest expense should approximate $140 million. Intersegment revenues should be about $160 million and the corresponding amount of margin to eliminate on these sales is $35 million. Our tax rate, 23%. Our CapEx will come down to approximately 300 to 350, all focused on -- or majority focus on revenue-generating assets. Corporate expenses should approximate $130 million and interest should be about $140 million.
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: Jim, it's a great question and it's one that I think we're wrestling with as well. As we've said, we're in the early stages of this cycle. But I can also tell you that we are working very, very closely with all of these customers in reviewing these projects. There will be some projects that will be awarded in 2015, no doubt. We expect that. But we do expect that there'll be some projects that we'd probably were looking at 6 months ago with more certainty that could get shoved to the right even further. If they -- we are all working with customers right now to recalibrate costs. There's a lot of work going on around standardization. There's a lot of work going on with these guys in terms of how to remove some degree of complexity within the projects that they're looking at. A lot of this work started last year. So while it's hard to predict exactly where we will land by the end of the year, we do think that we have more risk, obviously, in '15 than we probably were thinking just 3 to 6 months ago.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's true for all of us so that's okay. The idea of standardization in every deepwater field is high temperature, high pressure and a little bit different, but everybody is focusing on standardization. Like you say, you're working with your clients to c
componenttext: That's true for all of us so that's okay. The idea of standardization in every deepwater field is high temperature, high pressure and a little bit different, but everybody is focusing on standardization. Like you say, you're working with your clients to come up with better solutions. How long does it take to recalibrate the economics of deepwater? Is this a 2- or 3-quarter event? Or is this a 2-to-3-year event? Or is it somewhere in between?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was -- deepwater costs had started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought, and a lot
componenttext: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was -- deepwater costs had started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought, and a lot of that was customers pulling back due to costs. So the effort to look more at standard solutions. And when we talked about standard solutions, it's not reinventing the wheel on welding specs and metallurgies and -- it's using things that we have all developed in the course of developing prior projects that have proven to be very, very robust and fit for purpose and the scope of the environment that they're working in. So it's really getting people back to ground and back to things that we've already done. So you can actually catch up time and reduce time by doing this. So some of these projects that have been recalibrated for the last 6 months, we could see those cycle out here fairly -- sooner than later in 2015.

componenttext: Well, Kurt, let me say -- and I may let Chuck or Scott weigh in on this, but we have seen margins expand in 2014 in Subsea, but it's far from where we expected it to be. The business should be in the mid-teens. And so executing on our Subsea strategy, our OneSubsea strategy will get us there. But I think we all have to accept under the current market environment where we have excess capacity, the timing of when we get there is going to be somewhat questionable. headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: I wouldn't say that anyone is talking about newbuilds at this stage of where we're at. But I do see a very conscious discipline around taking the older-generation rigs out of the market permanently. And that's something we haven't seen in prior cycles. So even in this cycles as it started to come down, there were still a lot of the older-generation rigs competing for contracts. And as those does go away, I think you'll see a lot more confidence come back in drilling contractors' desire to upgrade and advance their fleets. So that's our view of it. And I would say it's one that's going to have to take some time to evolve.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So that -- you're right, Bill. The challenge there is how much price do we get and how much pressure do we get and how much can we leverage our supply chain to offset that. At this point, it's early stages, Bill. We're just -- our vision is a little
componenttext: Yes. So that -- you're right, Bill. The challenge there is how much price do we get and how much pressure do we get and how much can we leverage our supply chain to offset that. At this point, it's early stages, Bill. We're just -- our vision is a little clouded there. Would I believe that we can do better than we did in the '08, '09 cycle? The answer is yes. We think Surface will contract less than the activity levels would suggest for the reasons I have stated. And we think V&M will contract more for the reasons -- the distributor destocking. So you got to think about those things. But we are absolutely focused on the cost structure, our supply chain. What we've gone through in '14 prepares us so well and puts us so far ahead of this that I feel pretty comfortable, I feel very comfortable that our margin downdraft, absent something we're not expecting, should be less in this downcycle than it was in the last downcycle.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly, a more conceptual question with regard to Deepwater and Subsea in general. I hear you with regard to the reworking of project economics standardization and what have you. But I think one of the things that is troubling for Deepwat
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, a more conceptual question with regard to Deepwater and Subsea in general. I hear you with regard to the reworking of project economics standardization and what have you. But I think one of the things that is troubling for Deepwater coming out of this cycle, which we will eventually do so relative to 2009, is that the prospectivity of Deepwater looks diminished and the discoveries over the past 2 years, whether they prove to be transient or structural, but certainly are -- have been incredibly disappointing. And so how do you guys think about the Deepwater growth narrative coming out of this catharsis relative to where we were in 2009?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environm
componenttext: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environment where, and at least where we're going to be, may be constrained on a hydrocarbon price over the next several years. But I think you really have to go look at this instead of huge deepwater developments. We see a lot of opportunities with going in and creating new cheese, as they say, around existing environments and the stepouts and so forth that are already in place. So we're working with a lot of operators to go in the existing and older fields where infrastructure is there, utilize some of our Subsea processing technologies and some of the advances we're making in dual lift and lift systems to help change the economics of those opportunities. And we think that's going to create an incremental opportunity for the OneSubsea platform way into the future.

componenttextpreview: Well, first, we've got a great balance sheet. It's unbelievably well positioned for this downturn, so we're very comfortable there. I think we're going to have opportunities to invest organically in our business to take advantage of some dislocations that
componenttext: Well, first, we've got a great balance sheet. It's unbelievably well positioned for this downturn, so we're very comfortable there. I think we're going to have opportunities to invest organically in our business to take advantage of some dislocations that occur. Depending on the depth and length of this downcycle, people are going to get themselves in trouble. And you have seen in past downcycles, Cameron take advantage of that through combinations or acquisitions of assets that make sense for us to our own. And during this cycle, we've got authorization left and we would expect to continue buying some shares. I think it's going to be a combination of all those, but we are also very mindful that this is a downcycle and we are watching things carefully. We've got a phenomenal focus on pulling working capital out of this business as these contraction occurs. So I think we'll have a good cash flow year. We're going to make sure we do the right things with that cash and position ourselves even better when we come out of this.

componenttext: Well, our key focus on -- is expanding the core. As you know, we divested of the compression business since last year to really focus on our core oil and gas markets. So if you look at our core Drilling platform, Surface platform, Subsea and our Valve businesses, that kind of touches all of that. Whatever we can find that complements that and that gives us a strong service connection to the customer, that's going to be in our wheelhouse.

componenttext: Could you please speak to your pricing experience in the last downturn? Recognizing that it may not be the same, but just some context for us in Surface and V&M would be very helpful.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brad, right now every customer is asking for some degree of pricing relief and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle is that our overall pricing relief will be something far less than that. And how we have
componenttext: Yes. Brad, right now every customer is asking for some degree of pricing relief and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle is that our overall pricing relief will be something far less than that. And how we have to manage that is on a number of fronts, right? First of all there's internal cost and making sure that we can offset anything we do internally through just more efficient activities on ourselves or more through our own supply chain network. The other is really working with customers to broaden our share of their footprint where we can defer some of that cost across more volume. And that is something we were successful doing the last cycle. And I tell you, with the relationships we have with customers today, most of them are focused not only on costs but efficiency. How can they be more efficient at the well site, consume less product or consume less time. And we have -- we've got a great platform to work with them on that, especially on the Surface systems where we have the most efficient Surface wellhead system, literarily, in the world. And we've been able to prove that with a lot of customers. So we will leverage that to -- versus just roll over and concede pricing. And -- but it won't be as bad as what we are being asked to do, but I do think that we'll be able to offset a lot of our price discounting through more efficiencies internally. But we will not be able to escape it totally.

componenttext: So, Dave, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spend in the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects much more efficient in taking time and people out of the equation. And so typically on a large project, right, from the time you award to the time you start to deliver equipment is anywhere from a 2 -- you start to deliver equipment after year 1 into year 2 and year 3. And so what we're trying to do on our standardization effort and some of the other things that we're doing within OneSubsea is really try to shorten that cycle from time of order to time of equipment. And what we're doing is standardizing material specifications. Were standardizing quality plans. We're standardizing welding specifications. And by doing that, we're taking out a lot of people, we're taking out a lot of time. And anytime you can reduce that cycle time, you're driving pretty significant cost out of the equation. So we've been doing this now for about 3 years. We're having some very significant wins with some of our operators and partners. And I ultimately think that the overall costs will come down in a pretty significant magnitude as operators start to break some of the dynamics and possibly some of the bad habits that they are doing historically when developing these fields.

It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Lamb, Vice President, Investor Relations for Cameron. Thank you, Mr. Lamb, you may begin.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's Annual Report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of o
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Cameron reported fourth quarter earnings today of $1.34 per share from continued operations, excluding other costs, an increase of 33% versus year-ago quarter. The primary driver for these improved results was the operating performance of our Drilling and Surface segments, along with a significant reduction in the company's overhead expense. Most notably, our Drilling segment reported a 89% increase in operating income and an almost 700-basis-point improvement in margin relative to the year-ago quarter, while the Surface business reported a 23% increase in operating income. 
Consolidated SG&A expense declined 11% relative to the year-ago quarter. On a consolidated basis, these factors contributed to an operating income margin of 15% for Cameron. Additionally, the company generated $938 million of cash from operations during the quarter, an increase of 49% compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 and reflected, in part, our sharpened focus on reducing working capital.
Overall, 2014 was a great year for Cameron on a number of fronts. Most impressive was the turnaround story with our Drilling Systems. As previously mentioned, we saw a 700-basis-point improvement in margins versus year-ago levels. Even more importantly, we have now embedded both processes and work practices that have driven predictable success in executing our backlog.
We are also very pleased with the timing and the outcome of the divestiture process with compression. Not only did we generate $1.5 billion of sales proceeds, it also allowed us to sharpen our focus on Cameron's core oil and gas businesses. We implemented a number of cost reduction programs that began the process to streamline our support structure across all of our business units, which proved to be a meaningful contributor to improving overall margins. 
We returned $1.7 billion of cash to shareholders in 2014, while maintaining a very healthy balance sheet. And the momentum we created with investing and broadening the platform of our core businesses will benefit us in a market where customers' attention turns cost and efficiency versus just availability.
Now some comments regarding our outlook for 2015, and I will start with our onshore markets. Clearly, we are witnessing a very sharp correction in activity that will negatively impact our Surface, Valves and Drilling segments in 2015. North America will be impacted much harder than international. The degree to which North America activity will correct is still unknown. The range of possibilities will be heavily influenced by both the customer and the basin. 
Cameron has a broad presence in North America and we have a very broad customer base, mostly populated with IOCs, major independents and the major drilling contractors, all of which we see as a positive to have in this environment. Cameron also has a very large international onshore presence which will contract at a slower rate and in some markets could even expand. Cameron's customer base is made up mostly of large IOCs and NOCs whose attitudes towards investing through cycles have proven to be more predictable. 
As for our offshore and deepwater markets, OneSubsea, Drilling Systems and Valve markets will all be exposed to the pullback in spending we are witnessing, offshore as well. We saw the pause button hit on most deepwater drilling capital spending last year and nothing in our view has changed, with the exception that we are not seeing drilling contractors actually scrap older generation rigs. Something we have rarely seen in prior year cycles which, in time, is a positive for some form of newbuild recovery. We will seek some compression in the services part of our businesses due to the lower utilization and pricing, but we also see opportunity to serve a broader portfolio of products from our rig equipment acquisitions. 
As for Subsea projects, most every perspective project we are tracking has or is going through a recalibration process for both scope and price. Some of this work actually started last year. While we fully expect to see projects awarded in 2015, the value or result of these exercises may be different from what we were thinking 6 months ago. The importance of deepwater projects in our customers' portfolios has not changed. The timing on which one cycle to the forefront and the current cost environment will, which all plays to the strengths that OneSubsea was created to deliver.
Having said all of that, I'll remind you that Cameron has a substantial backlog of work. And that backlog provides us with good visibility into a portion of our 2015 operating revenues and margins. And our confidence to deliver that backlog at the margins and in the time frame we have in our plan is very high, given the performance we've seen throughout 2014.
However, we will see our equally, if not more important, shorter-cycle book and bill businesses meaningfully impacted by the current environment. And the speed in which we have seen the correction in this cycle over the past months has created significant uncertainty with the degree that this will impact both the revenues and margins of our short-cycle businesses, especially those in North America.
Given we're still very early in the cycle, it would be challenging to predict the range of outcomes within our budget and, therefore, feel it's prudent not providing annual EPS guidance for 2015. Chuck will, however, provide detailed commentary on each of our operating segments.
While trying to speculate on the depth and duration of this cycle, corrections will be difficult. Rest assured that Cameron will stay very close to our customers to ensure we are advancing and investing the most cost-efficient solutions for their operations, not compromise on our commitment to service and execution excellence, aggressively manage our cost structure to the reality of the business and be opportunistic towards expanding our core platforms. You can also expect us to leverage our broad product, customer and geographic diversity to expand share. Every operator is currently reviewing their supplier's performance to ensure that they have the most cost-effective partner in this environment, and that will open doors for Cameron. This competitive drive will help us weather this cycle, as we have weathered previous cycles, and emerge as an even more formidable company over the longer term.
I will now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever, while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structu
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Before we I get into what we need to do in 2015, I would like to reiterate what Jack said regarding our performance in 2014. Cameron had our safest year ever, while providing products and services at a record level. We drove our cost structure down every quarter in 2014 while performing at this record activity rate. The focus on execution, cost reduction and servicing our customers results in strong margin progression throughout the year. The fourth quarter results were a culmination of a lot of hard work and diligence that positions the enterprise in a better place to perform on the challenges that we face in 2015.
Now let's switch gears to the present, in 2015. The weak macro environment that Jack described is certainly evident when you look at Cameron's orders and backlog position in the fourth quarter of 2014. Our book-to-bill ratio in the quarter was 0.7:1, as order intake declined in all of our businesses on a sequential quarter basis. There were, however, a couple of bright spots of customer activity during the fourth quarter. In particular, we booked a multiyear contract with ExxonMobil for topside wellhead equipment and production trees for the Hebron project, a 52-well development located offshore Newfoundland, as well as OneSubsea's execution of a Subsea well-intervention alliance with Helix and Schlumberger. 
Nevertheless, the order flow was weak and the net result of that was a decline in our backlog to roughly $9.5 billion at the end of the quarter. Despite the reduction in backlog, the backlog itself is substantial, especially in our longer-cycle businesses, OneSubsea and Drilling. The organization is highly focused on our ability to execute our backlog and the operational improvements realized in 2014 will carry over into 2015.
As Jack said, in this challenging macro environment, Cameron is absolutely focused on the things they can control. We are committed to our objective of delivering steady improvement in our consolidated operating margins, on average, over time. To be clear, over a multiyear period, some of this improvement could be temporarily masked by pricing pressure and reduced volumes, but we are confident in our ability to keep advancing this program over the long term and driving excellence in our ability to execute.
We are seeking to do this through continuous improvements in virtually every aspect of our operations, from our supply chain to product delivery, and throughout our corporate and support services organizations. We are finding ways to work smarter, faster and more efficiently and more creatively in everything we do. 
We also want to ensure that we're operating at maximum cost effectiveness. The cost-reduction steps that were taken in 2014 are helping us prepare for 2015. We will and have already taken further cost reductions in the first quarter, and we will continue to aggressively drive our cost structure down throughout the year as we work off the existing backlog.
In addition to volume reduction, the other challenge we are facing is pricing. The majority of our customers are seeking or have already asked for price concessions to help them weather the current environment. The Cameron response to this request has been a proactive and collaborative approach. We are working with our customers to provide improved technology in processes that will reduce their overall spending commitments and their operating costs. We feel that the largest cost savings for operators will come from a drive towards standardization, improved technology and further customer integration. We are in the early days, but we are already seeing a few wins with this approach.
Each of our businesses will have different drivers and behave differently throughout the downcycle. Having completed our divestiture program in 2014, we are committed to each of our 4 operating segments, and I am confident that we will emerge through this cycle better than ever. OneSubsea will continue to build on the Pore to Process approach that will help operators improve their overall recovery in their deepwater developments. We continue to progress in this endeavor and operators will need help finding cost-effective solutions that generate higher production from their deepwater assets.
Our Surface division is well positioned as the market leader to continue to outperform on a relative basis and grow market share by providing the highest service level and the best reliability in the industry. In Drilling, we will take this opportunity in the downturn to complete a comprehensive and integrated drilling offering. Our Valves & Measurement segment touches everything we do in Cameron in every segment of our businesses. We will leverage the breadth and knowledge within the enterprise to ensure that Valves & Measurement outperforms in this business cycle.
While we are actively and realistically facing the current market situation, Cameron is poised to take advantage of the opportunities that will present themselves. We're being proactive in our approach to manage our customers and our cost structure. We have a highly engaged team and we have a relentless drive towards excellence. The activities and programs that we are implementing now will position Cameron for a long-term success and outperformance throughout the cycle. 
I'll now turn it over to Chuck for the financials.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts their models. Revenues for the quarter w
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Before I get into the details of the quarter, I just want to remind everybody that Scott Lamb is available after the call to help everybody work through the new segment reporting and how it impacts their models. 
Revenues for the quarter were $2.8 billion, a 5% increase sequentially. Segment operating income margins were 15% for the quarter, flat sequentially but up 200 basis points from prior year level. Corporate expenses for the quarter were $35 million and EPS before other costs was a $1.34, an all-time quarterly record.
The key message in our fourth quarter financials is the operating margin improvement we've made throughout 2014. The improvements have come from better efficiency in our plants, as well as tight control over our costs, and these will serve us well during the downturn.
Subsea revenues increased 12% sequentially, while its operating margin improved to 10%, reflecting the strength of our margin and backlog. We are pleased with the sequential progression and recognize the need to continue to grow our services offering in this segment to further enhance margins.
Our Surface revenues increased 10% sequentially and represented the highest revenue level in our history, driven primarily by North America. This operating margin improved 110 basis points sequentially, driven by the higher revenue level as well as improved mix in North America.
Drilling's revenues increased 2% sequentially. To give you some perspective on the improvements Drilling has made over the last 12 months, the fourth quarter revenue is 20% higher than it was in the year-ago period. Operating margin for Drilling was 18.5%, which is below the previous quarter simply due to mix. The fourth quarter operating margin is 850 basis points higher than the low point we saw in Q1 of this year.
V&M revenues decreased 5% sequentially, as it has struggled with orders and pricing in its engineered valve lines all year. As a result, we were hit hard this quarter with absorption challenges and lower-margin engineered valve shipments, which resulted in a decline in Q4 operating margin to 15.3%. We're in the midst of completing a realignment of this segment, which will allow us to capture additional market share while lowering our costs at the same time.
Cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter was $938 million, obviously, a record level, as our working capital efficiency drive begins to show results. As a result, we ended the year with $1.6 billion of cash and short-term investments. As we announced earlier in the month, we completed our sale of our Centrifugal Compression business. And our net proceeds, after taxes, are estimated to be $600 million. As a result of the sale, we will recognize that estimated gain, for financial statement purposes, of approximately $400 million, which will be reflected in discontinued ops in Q1.
We purchased 3.4 million shares of our stock during the quarter, and we ended the year with $476 million of availability under our authorization. The strength of our balance sheet puts us in the position to take advantage of opportunities as they arise during the course of this downcycle. Whether they be through organic investments in our business, acquisitions or just in share repurchases.
Now turning to the 2015 outlook. We are confident in our ability to execute our backlog, $5.7 billion of which is scheduled to ship out in '15. However, our shorter-cycle businesses, which generated $4.4 billion of revenues in '14, will be challenged by the current market conditions. Our customers are continuing to adjust their spending plans, which has clouded our ability to predict what the level of shorter-cycle revenue will be in '15.
As a result, we do not believe we can provide you accurate guidance regarding earnings per share given the uncertainty around our shorter-cycle businesses, and that explains why we're discussing our segments in more detail. We do believe that our new segment presentation will aid investors in thinking about the range of possible earnings Cameron may generate in this uncertain market.
To help you think through each of our segments, I'll cover some important points. Our Subsea segment has a significant portion of its 2015 revenues and backlog. In fact, $2.1 billion of its backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. To help you think about how Subsea shorter-cycles businesses may affect its 2015 revenue, 2014 saw approximately $800 million of such revenue, which primarily represents services. These services typically do not experience as much contraction in a downmarket as does our Surface segment. Therefore, we see a lot less revenue risks in this segment. Given our focus on backlog margins over the past several years, our Subsea segment should see margin expansion in 2015 when compared to the full year '14 margin of 6.7. However, it will come down from the fourth quarter level of 10%.
With the success of our CAM Shell initiative over the last 4 years, our Surface segment has become heavier weighted towards a more service-intensive North American market. Therefore, the current market correction will have a pronounced impact on the North American portion of this segment. However, the international portion, which comprises half of Surface, will be more insulated from the current macro environment.
A few data points: Approximately $750 million of Surface's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, Surface had approximately $1.7 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, which will be impacted by the reduced activity levels. While our customers are typically the more longer-term-focused customers, Surface will not be immune from the reduced activity levels nor the pricing pressures which are being experienced in North America. Surface's shorter-cycle business is somewhat protected from the full blunt of the reduced activity level due to the value proposition we deliver to our customers. However, it will certainly see downward pressure on its operating margin in '15.
Drilling has approximately $2 billion of its backlog which will ship in '15. In 2014, Drilling had approximately $800 million of shorter-cycle businesses, which is centered around our services and land BOP markets. Therefore, this portion of the business will be impacted by the downcycle. However, continued improvement in internal efficiency could allow us to grow Drilling's 2015 operating margin slightly from '14's level of 15.5%, depending on the ultimate level of pricing pressure we experience. 
Approximately $850 million of V&M's backlog is scheduled to ship in '15. In 2014, V&M had approximately $1.2 billion of shorter-cycle businesses, a significant amount of which was focused on North America activity. V&M is different than Surfaces' North American business, and that a significant portion of V&M North American business goes through distributors. 
During cyclical downturns, V&M experiences a painful destocking process, whereby distributors bleed off existing inventories before ordering new inventory. Therefore, the downturn will have a more significant impact on V&M's revenue when compared to Surfaces. This revenue decline will put significant downward pressure on V&M's operating margin percent.
Now a few overall comments for Cameron. Cameron's consolidated operating margin, which includes corporate expenses but excludes interests and other costs, contracted 170 basis points during the '08 downturn. While the company is much different today than it was during the 2008 time period, we will certainly see a contraction still in our 2015 overall consolidated margin. At this time, however, we see that contraction being somewhat less than the 170 basis points I mentioned.
A few other 2015 items. Interest expense should approximate $140 million. Intersegment revenues should be about $160 million and the corresponding amount of margin to eliminate on these sales is $35 million. Our tax rate, 23%. Our CapEx will come down to approximately 300 to 350, all focused on -- or majority focus on revenue-generating assets. Corporate expenses should approximate $130 million and interest should be about $140 million.
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was -- deepwater costs had started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought, and a lot
componenttext: I don't think so. I think, we really started this in earnings last year. There was -- deepwater costs had started the cycle up and a lot of concerns around it. You know that last year's overall awards were not to the degree everyone had thought, and a lot of that was customers pulling back due to costs. So the effort to look more at standard solutions. And when we talked about standard solutions, it's not reinventing the wheel on welding specs and metallurgies and -- it's using things that we have all developed in the course of developing prior projects that have proven to be very, very robust and fit for purpose and the scope of the environment that they're working in. So it's really getting people back to ground and back to things that we've already done. So you can actually catch up time and reduce time by doing this. So some of these projects that have been recalibrated for the last 6 months, we could see those cycle out here fairly -- sooner than later in 2015.

componenttext: Well, Kurt, let me say -- and I may let Chuck or Scott weigh in on this, but we have seen margins expand in 2014 in Subsea, but it's far from where we expected it to be. componenttext: I wouldn't say that anyone is talking about newbuilds at this stage of where we're at. componenttext: Great question, Bill. And I would say it's one of the reasons we love having our partner with OneSubsea. Because we realized that the constraints on Deepwater are going to be more around reservoir recovery and how do you make that optimized in an environment where, and at least where we're going to be, may be constrained on a hydrocarbon price over the next several years. But I think you really have to go look at this instead of huge deepwater developments. We see a lot of opportunities with going in and creating new cheese, as they say, around existing environments and the stepouts and so forth that are already in place. So we're working with a lot of operators to go in the existing and older fields where infrastructure is there, utilize some of our Subsea processing technologies and some of the advances we're making in dual lift and lift systems to help change the economics of those opportunities. And we think that's going to create an incremental opportunity for the OneSubsea platform way into the future.

componenttext: Well, first, we've got a great balance sheet. It's unbelievably well positioned for this downturn, so we're very comfortable there. I think we're going to have opportunities to invest organically in our business to take advantage of some dislocations that occur. Depending on the depth and length of this downcycle, people are going to get themselves in trouble. componenttext: Yes. Brad, right now every customer is asking for some degree of pricing relief and I would say most of it is in a double-digit context. What we saw in the last cycle is that our overall pricing relief will be something far less than that. And how we have to manage that is on a number of fronts, right? First of all there's internal cost and making sure that we can offset anything we do internally through just more efficient activities on ourselves or more through our own supply chain network. The other is really working with customers to broaden our share of their footprint where we can defer some of that cost across more volume. And that is something we were successful doing the last cycle. And I tell you, with the relationships we have with customers today, most of them are focused not only on costs but efficiency. How can they be more efficient at the well site, consume less product or consume less time. And we have -- we've got a great platform to work with them on that, especially on the Surface systems where we have the most efficient Surface wellhead system, literarily, in the world. And we've been able to prove that with a lot of customers. So we will leverage that to -- versus just roll over and concede pricing. And -- but it won't be as bad as what we are being asked to do, but I do think that we'll be able to offset a lot of our price discounting through more efficiencies internally. But we will not be able to escape it totally.

componenttext: So, Dave, I mean just the Subsea hardware side, the SPS, if you will, is not the majority spend in the Deepwater development cost. But what ourselves and the peer group on providing the Subsea equipment are doing are really trying to make those projects much more efficient in taking time and people out of the equation. And so typically on a large project, right, from the time you award to the time you start to deliver equipment is anywhere from a 2 -- you start to deliver equipment after year 1 into year 2 and year 3. And so what we're trying to do on our standardization effort and some of the other things that we're doing within OneSubsea is really try to shorten that cycle from time of order to time of equipment. And what we're doing is standardizing material specifications. Were standardizing quality plans. We're standardizing welding specifications. And by doing that, we're taking out a lot of people, we're taking out a lot of time. And anytime you can reduce that cycle time, you're driving pretty significant cost out of the equation. So we've been doing this now for about 3 years. We're having some very significant wins with some of our operators and partners. And I ultimately think that the overall costs will come down in a pretty significant magnitude as operators start to break some of the dynamics and possibly some of the bad habits that they are doing historically when developing these fields.
