headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2015 compared to the $0.95 we earned in the second quarter of 2014.
Our financial results reflect a strong execution across the enterprise, specifically driven by our Subsea and Drilling segments. In addition, we continue to realize the benefits from our systemic cost-reduction programs across the Cameron enterprise that resulted in a 16% decline in our SG&A expense from a year ago.
Cyclical downturn continues to create uncertainty across all of the markets we serve, especially in relation to our shorter-cycle businesses. Broadly speaking, that uncertainty has caused demand to remain muted. Additionally, we continue to seek pricing pressure across all of our business segments.
Onshore markets have continued to be weak in North America, but we are seeing some evidence that the cycle maybe approaching a trough. One reason we say that is that we have seen a deceleration in the rate of order declines in our onshore North America businesses. Specifically, orders for North American onshore declined only 9% from Q1 to Q2 as compared to a roughly 40% decline from Q4 to Q1. As we've previously said, international markets approved to be a bit more resilient, and we actually saw an uptick in new orders internationally from our Surface systems businesses from Q1 to Q2.
When we look at the offshore markets, we continue to see demand for drilling products contract sharply when we compared to the year-ago quarter. That said, we did see a sequential quarter uptick in our orders for our Drilling Systems business.
In our Subsea business, the story is much more positive this quarter, with orders up both sequentially and as compared to the year-ago period. That both timing and scope of Deepwater production systems remains a question, our OneSubsea continues to see a healthy profit lift for Subsea processing awards. Strength of the prospect lift in our OneSubsea joint venture is a reflection of the competitive advantages of our offering. And again, more broadly, as both producers and suppliers collaborate to lower capital costs, increased recovery and reduce the cost per barrel, we believe many of these projects should ultimately move forward.
I have to take a step back and think about the bigger picture for Cameron, we're very fortunate to have a diverse offering of products and services that allows us to participate in the broader markets, both onshore and offshore, that make up our customer spending. To put a finer point on it, this means that Cameron is poised to benefit regardless of which particular and market recovers first.
We're encouraged by what we think are early signs of moderation in the pace of the decline in customer spending. As we have said previously, in the current environment, we remain focused on the things that we can control: Ongoing systemic reduction in our cost structure, excellence in execution, creating and maintaining strong customer relationships, growing our core platforms and steady investment in new technology. We believe this focus will ensure that the company generates long-term value for all of our stakeholders.
I'll now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer. Scott?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. More briefly after Jack's comment on the company's quarterly financial performance, we did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment, we made our decisions, we moved quickly, we're doing wha
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. More briefly after Jack's comment on the company's quarterly financial performance, we did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment, we made our decisions, we moved quickly, we're doing what we need to do and we did all of this while embracing our customers during this difficult time.
While Chuck walk you to the details of our earnings, but I do want to talk about a bit about of orders. The headline here is that on a consolidated basis, orders increased 15% sequentially. In our Subsea segment, orders were 32% above the first quarter of 2015, and the book-to-bill ratio for the Subsea segment was well above 1.
Clearly, OneSubsea has maintained good momentum through this cyclical downturn. Second quarter accomplishments include: A $330 million award for Subsea production equipment for our project offshore North Africa; our front-end engineering design contract with Woodside for proposed floating LNG development, Offshore Northwest Australia. Woodside order's particularly exciting for us, because it's the first contact we have won under the frame agreement we signed with them a year ago, and we expect more to come under this agreement; the signing of an alliance agreement with Subsea 7 to further round out the OneSubsea portfolio. The alliance will work closely with our clients to optimize the Subsea production hardware and the Subsea on vocals, risers and full lines and cost-effective solutions for operators. This is a further link in the chain of our Pore to Process approach that aimed at reducing development costs for our customers and as importantly, improving the recovery factor in Deepwater developments.
Additionally, the signing of the agreement with Chevron to form a joint industry program to develop Subsea technology for 20K applications. This is a natural migration of Cameron's high pressure technology that we have already developed and deployed in our Drilling and Surface businesses.
And finally, as we're announcing today, a significant award within the quarter for a Subsea boosting system in the Gulf of Mexico. We'll provide more details on this award in upcoming press release.
Looking at our other segments. Orders were also up on a sequential basis for Surface and Drilling by 5% and 23%, respectively. The increase in surface was driven by international new equipment orders. The increase in drilling was aided by gains in services and new equipment, including several jack-up orders. 
Orders in Valves & Measurement declined sequentially by about 5%, which is broadly reflective of what we are seeing in terms of overall demand.
In the execution front, our operation teams are performing well within the context of what is happening in this marketplace, with our customers and the competition. Specifically, we continue to execute our downturn playbook that we had put together last year outlining a program to build better customer relations, develop technology for the future, optimize our internal processes and drive down our cost structure.
Let me sight a few examples on this. As the first playbook relates to customers, I will say that we are having the kinds of discussions today that we would never had a year ago. Discussions that are much more collaborative and often coming much earlier in the life of the cycle of a project. Customers and suppliers are working together to eliminate some of the inefficiencies that crept into the business in the area of high oil prices. Many of our customer discussions are about finding specific ways to improve operational efficiencies and to improve the return on capital for their investments. Clearly, operators today realized that collaboration with suppliers has the potential to unlock new and creative approaches that will save money and generate returns in this market. Our ultimate objective in this discussion is an outcome that reduces cost for the customer while enabling Cameron to gain share and maintain margin. In other words, a win-win situation.
A playbook in relation to new technology is essentially this, a commitment to maintain our R&D spending throughout the cycle. We believe that technology spending is essential for us to retain our competitive advantage. We've seen some of these results with our recent accomplishments. First, the world's first gas compressor -- wet gas compression for which we won an OTC Spotlight award; mark for high available to control pod for BOPs, which also won an OTC Spotlight award; the industry's first and only 13.58 [ph] 25K [ph] blowout preventer in the first to market with the 25K surface production system. A joint technology program between OneSubsea and Helix to engineer and manufacture a 15K intervention riser system as well as a 20K joint industry program with Chevron that I mentioned a moment ago.
The last element of our downturn playbook is a companywide effort to reduce a fundamental cost structure. This effort started prior to the downturn and has helped us minimize the margin impact on our businesses. Essentially, we have taken a fresh look at everything we do and challenged ourselves to drive efficiency throughout our organization. 
As a practical matter, and what this means is that we are streamlining internal processes and organizations. We're significantly reducing the cost structure of the organization through reorganization, improved processes and leveraging the entire Cameron enterprise. One visible example of this is the 16% reduction in our SG&A, as Jack cited earlier. We will continue to do what we need to do to rightsize our business and this environment while creating a scalable model that will allow us to grow profitably -- will allow us to grow more profitably than in past up cycles when the recovery ultimately does come.
Again, overall market conditions are challenging but we are seeing signs of activity stabilizing in North America, and that will help our onshore-focused businesses, which include Surface, Valves & Measurement and portions of our Drilling segment; recover relatively quickly once we see activity levels actually increase.
Our Subsea segment is making steady progress in demonstrating how we can help customers improve recoveries. For this reason, we reiterate our view that Subsea orders will be at or above 2014 order levels, with the back half of for the year weighted to the fourth quarter.
We believe the breadth of our portfolio will allow us to take advantage of the marketplace, despite the shape or style of the recovery. We remain committed to our multiyear margin improvement program, and we believe that our ability to generate solid results thus far during a tough market is a clear indication that we are on the right path.
On that note, I'll turn it over to Chuck.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments: Subsea was up 4% sequentially; revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-to-
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments: Subsea was up 4% sequentially; revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-to-quarter; revenues in Surface and V&M were down sequentially about 6% and 11%, respectively. The good news is that the pace of these declines in our shorter-cycle components of Surface and V&M seem to be moderating.
EBIT margins before other costs were 12.1% for the quarter, which is 50 basis points higher when compared to the year quarter -- year-ago quarter, down sequentially about 70 basis points. No surprise there, as our Surface business reflects the level of North American activity declines. However, it appears that surface margins may have bottomed in Q2. As both Jack and Scott mentioned, we've been working on fundamentally lowering our cost structure since early '14, and our second quarter results show further evidence of our progress in this regard.
Consolidated SG&A expense was down 16% versus a year-ago quarter and also modestly below the level of Q1. Operating EPS was $0.83, which was below the year-ago quarter and below the first quarter of this year. That's no surprise given the market conditions.
Excluding from operating earnings and our other costs amounting to $0.12 per share primarily for restructuring costs to valuation an ongoing currency and accelerated write-downs of underutilize assets. Now a few words about each segment.
Subsea revenues declined from the levels of the year-ago quarter due to the timing of project deliveries. That being said, revenues increased on a sequential basis as expected. Q1 represented the seasonal low point for Subsea revenues. Operating income margins came in at 10.2%, almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and also above Q1, with improved execution and cost reduction.
Surface revenues were down versus the year-ago quarter and on a sequential quarter basis, due largely to the weakness in the shorter-cycle North American market. The North American revenues for Surface, which accounted for -- which account for most of the shorter-cycle businesses, were down 41% from the year-ago quarter and down 19% from the preceding quarter. Our international market actually grew on both a year-over-year and sequential basis.
The operating income margin for Surface was 13.5%. Q2 margin reflects continued weakness in activity levels in North America as well as pricing pressure. Operating income margin for Surface in Q2 was also negatively impacted by FX losses, which lowered the margin by 80 basis points. For sake of clarity, what I'm referring to is FX losses represent balance sheet remeasurement of our net monetary positions in that segment.
In drilling, no surprise on the revenue front. Revenues were 6% below the level of a year-ago, but essentially flat sequentially. Decline in revenues versus the year-ago quarter was driven by our shorter-cycle services businesses as the steep production activity levels have clearly affected our drilling customers' spending patterns. The operating income margin in drilling was 16.6%, which is almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and clearly shows the improved execution of this business. The Q2 margin was down on a sequential quarter basis, due primarily to FX losses, which lowered Drillings operating income margin by approximately 100 basis points.
In our V&M segment, revenues declined sharply in comparison to the year-ago quarter and the first quarter '15. Again, this should come as no surprise to anyone given the weakness in the North American market. North American revenues for V&M, which represents most of its shorter-cycle businesses, were down about 19% as compared to the preceding quarter and 33% down from the year-ago quarter. As Scott mentioned, we've begun to see signs that the North American portion of this business has began to stabilize.
Operating income margin in V&M was 11.5%, which was modestly up from the level of Q1 as expected. Net sequential quarter improvement is attributable to cost-reduction efforts.
The Q2 margin was well below the level of year-ago, reflecting the impact of the destocking of distributor inventories in North America. Corporate expense declined by $15 million from year-ago levels, reflecting our strategic shift to a lower-cost operating model. The company ended the quarter with cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments totaling $1.7 billion, a net debt to cap ratio of 17%. Cameron's overall liquidity gives us significant flexibility to deal with the uncertainties presented by this downcycle, execute on our strategic initiatives and position ourselves for growth.
Cameron's CapEx was $41 million in the second quarter as compared to $73 million in the second quarter '14. As of the end of the second quarter '15, approximately $285 million remained under our share repurchase program.
Now let's turn to outlook. Overall, Q2 revenue -- overall revenues in Q3 and 4 [indiscernible] around the levels of Q2. As far as overall EBIT margin goes, Q3 should remain around the level of Q2 before we see a slight uptick in Q4.
On that note, let's look at each of the 4 segments.
Our Subsea segment, we expect to see revenues in the second half of '15 that are well above first half levels, with Subsea's operating income margin for the second half topping 10%. In our Surface segment, we are likely to see second half revenues that are somewhat lower than half 1. We believe that Q2 is likely to be the low point for Surface margins this year and could see slight increases for Q3 and 4.
In our Drilling segment, second half revenues are likely to be moderately below half 1 levels, maybe around 10% lower. We think the operating income margin will increase in each of the remaining quarters and could approach 20% in Q4. In our Valves & Measurement segment, second half revenues are likely to be somewhat below half 1, with quarterly revenues not bearing materially from the level of Q2.
A few other '15 items to mention. Corporate expenses should be approximately $100 million for the year, which is $10 million lower than our previous guidance of $110 million, interest expense should approximate $140 million and our segment revenue should approximate $200 million. The corresponding amount of intercompany operating income to eliminate would be roughly $50 million. Our operating tax rate should approximate 23%, our CapEx will be in the approximate range from $300 million to $350 million and noncontrolling interest should be around $50 million.
With that, Scott, let's open up for questions.

And so those are great discussions to be having right now, and our guys are very busy talking to operators about how they improve their recovery rates.

componenttext: Yes. I think every reservoir is different. And I'll just add that the beauty of OneSubsea, right, is having a party like Summer J is we do have a team that really understands the reservoir and understands the flow aspects and flow assurance side of that and we can have meaningful discussions with operators around what we think their developments can do and what's the potential on that. So we feel very good about that. When you think of Deepwater versus onshore recovery rates, in the Deepwater, the best wells are still in the teens that maybe a 20%, whereas onshore, you're getting upwards of 30% to 50% recovery. So the goal is to convert Deepwater wells and get them ultimately to look something like the onshore wells. And we think we can do that by putting energy on the seafloor and being able to intervene in those wells on a regular basis to help stimulate production. So there's not 1 magic number, there's not a benchmark we've talked about, but when we think in sit down with operators and really start to understand what their reservoir characteristics are, we ultimately think that we can improve the recovery rates, and we talked about different solutions to do that.

componenttext: Yes, so I think it is true. And so what we're doing is sitting down with teams with the IOCs and say, okay, well let us look at this one and maybe you've got a wrong assumption there on pump light or a different assumption on flow assurance. componenttext:
Thank you, Christine. I would like to make a few closing comments where in the call today.
Just to say the least, this is a very challenging market for our industry. I'm very proud of the manner in which our team has met and led meeting these challenges head-on. And I firmly believe that what would differentiate the winners in this market and then the ultimately recovery, is the resolve to transform your cost structure to meet today's reality as well as leverage the recovery and beyond. To develop customer relationships that are truly built on the value of what you deliver, you must be relentless on execution, innovation, quality and service excellence. Cameron's very fortunate to have a management team that gets this, and leading this effort is Scott Rowe, who has been instrumental in driving all our performance across all of these fronts.
As you all know, Scott will transition in the role of a CEO in October as I move in to the role of Chairman. And each of you on this call along with the rest of our stakeholders can be assured that Scott's passion for excellence, along with a genuine gift to lead people and organizations to ensure that Cameron will outperform in this cycle and well beyond. It's been a privilege and an honor to have the opportunity to lead a great company like Cameron, and I thank all of you for your support along the journey. Thanks.

componenttext:
Thank you, Christine. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cameron Second Quarter Earnings Call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter, and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the safe harbor provisions of the securities laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and, as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's annual report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2015 compared to the $0.95 we earned in the second quarter of 2014.
Our financial results reflect a strong execution across the enterprise, specifically driven by our Subsea and Drilling segments. In addition, we continue to realize the benefits from our systemic cost-reduction programs across the Cameron enterprise that resulted in a 16% decline in our SG&A expense from a year ago.
Cyclical downturn continues to create uncertainty across all of the markets we serve, especially in relation to our shorter-cycle businesses. Broadly speaking, that uncertainty has caused demand to remain muted. Additionally, we continue to see pricing pressure across all of our business segments.
Onshore markets have continued to be weak in North America, but we are seeing some evidence that the cycle may be approaching a trough. One reason we say that is that we have seen a deceleration in the rate of order declines in our onshore North America businesses. Specifically, orders for North American onshore declined only 9% from Q1 to Q2 as compared to a roughly 40% decline from Q4 to Q1. As we've previously said, international markets have proved to be a bit more resilient, and we actually saw an uptick in new orders internationally from our Surface Systems businesses from Q1 to Q2.
When we look at the offshore markets, we continue to see demand for drilling products contract sharply when we compared to the year-ago quarter. That said, we did see a sequential quarter uptick in our orders for our Drilling Systems business.
In our Subsea business, the story is much more positive this quarter, with orders up both sequentially and as compared to the year-ago period. And while both timing and scope of deepwater production systems remains a question, our OneSubsea continues to see a healthy prospect list for Subsea processing awards. Strength of the prospect list in our OneSubsea joint venture is a reflection of the competitive advantages of our offering. And again, more broadly, as both producers and suppliers collaborate to lower capital cost, increased recovery and reduce the cost per barrel, we believe many of these projects should ultimately move forward.
Now to take a step back and think about the bigger picture for Cameron, we're very fortunate to have a diverse offering of products and services that allows us to participate in the broader markets, both onshore and offshore, that make up our customer spending. To put a finer point on it, this means that Cameron is poised to benefit regardless of which particular end market recovers first.
We're encouraged by what we think are early signs of moderation in the pace of the decline in customer spending. As we have said previously, in the current environment, we remain focused on the things that we can control: ongoing systemic reduction in our cost structure, excellence in execution, creating and maintaining strong customer relationships, growing our core platforms and steady investment in new technology. We believe this focus will ensure that the company generates long-term value for all of our stakeholders.
I will now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer. Scott?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. I'll briefly echo Jack's comments on the company's quarterly financial performance. We did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment. We made hard decisions. We moved quickly. We're doing wh
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. I'll briefly echo Jack's comments on the company's quarterly financial performance. We did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment. We made hard decisions. We moved quickly. We're doing what we need to do, and we did all of this while embracing our customers during this difficult time.
I'll let Chuck walk you through the details of our earnings, but I do want to talk a bit about Cameron's orders. The headline here is that on a consolidated basis, orders increased 15% sequentially. In our Subsea segment, orders were 32% above the first quarter of 2015, and the book-to-bill ratio for the Subsea segment was well above 1. Clearly, OneSubsea has maintained good momentum through this cyclical downturn. Second quarter accomplishments include a $330 million award for subsea production equipment for a project offshore North Africa; a front-end engineering design contract with Woodside for a proposed floating LNG development offshore Northwest Australia. The Woodside order is particularly exciting for us because it's the first contract we have won under the frame agreement we signed with them a year ago, and we expect more to come under this agreement. 
The signing of an alliance agreement with Subsea 7 to further round out the OneSubsea portfolio. The alliance will work closely with our clients to optimize the subsea production hardware and the subsea umbilicals, risers and flowlines and drive cost-effective solutions for operators. This is a further link in the chain of our Pore to Process approach that aimed at reducing development cost for our customers and, as importantly, improving the recovery factor in deepwater developments.
Additionally, the signing of the agreement with Chevron to form a joint industry program to develop subsea technology for 20K applications. This is a natural migration of Cameron's high-pressure technology that we have already developed and deployed in our Drilling and Surface businesses.
And finally, as we're announcing today, a significant award within the quarter for a subsea boosting system in the Gulf of Mexico. We'll provide more details on this award in an upcoming press release.
Looking at our other segments, orders were also up on a sequential basis for Surface and Drilling by 5% and 23%, respectively. The increase in Surface was driven by international new equipment orders. The increase in Drilling was aided by gains in services and new equipment, including several jack-up orders. 
Orders in Valves & Measurement declined sequentially by about 5%, which is broadly reflective of what we are seeing in terms of overall demand.
In the execution front, our operations teams are performing well within the context of what is happening in this marketplace, with our customers and the competition. Specifically, we continue to execute our downturn playbook that we had put together last year, outlining a program to build better customer relations, develop technology for the future, optimize our internal processes and drive down our cost structure.
Let me cite a few examples on this. As the first playbook relates to customers, I will say that we are having the kinds of discussions today that we would never had a year ago, discussions that are much more collaborative and often coming much earlier in the life of the cycle of a project. Customers and suppliers are working together to eliminate some of the inefficiencies that crept into the business in the era of high oil prices. Many of our customer discussions are about finding specific ways to improve operational efficiencies and to improve the return on capital for their investments. Clearly, operators today realize that collaboration with suppliers has the potential to unlock new and creative approaches that will save money and generate returns in this market. Our ultimate objective in this discussion is an outcome that reduces cost for the customer while enabling Cameron to gain share and maintain margin, in other words, a win-win situation.
The playbook in relation to new technology is essentially this, a commitment to maintain our R&D spending throughout the cycle. We believe that technology spending is essential for us to retain our competitive advantages. We've seen some of these results with our recent accomplishments: first, the world's first gas compressor -- wet gas compressor for which we won an OTC Spotlight award; Mark IV High Availability Control POD for BOPs, which also won an OTC Spotlight award; the industry's first and only 13-5/8" 25K blowout preventer and the first to market with a 25K surface production system; a joint technology program between OneSubsea and Helix to engineer and manufacture a 15K intervention riser system; as well as a 20K joint industry program with Chevron that I mentioned a moment ago.
The last element of our downturn playbook is our company-wide effort to reduce our fundamental cost structure. This effort started prior to the downturn and has helped us minimize the margin impact on our businesses. Essentially, we have taken a fresh look at everything we do and challenged ourselves to drive efficiency throughout our organization. As a practical matter, what this means is that we are streamlining internal processes and organizations. We're significantly reducing the cost structure of the organization through reorganization, improved processes and leveraging the entire Cameron enterprise. One visible example of this is the 16% reduction in our SG&A, as Jack cited earlier. We will continue to do what we need to do to rightsize our business in this environment while creating a scalable model that will allow us to grow profitably -- will allow us to grow more profitably than in past up-cycles when the recovery ultimately does come.
Again, overall market conditions are challenging, but we are seeing signs of activity stabilizing in North America, and that will help our onshore-focused businesses, which include Surface, Valves & Measurement and portions of our Drilling segment, recover relatively quickly once we see activity levels actually increase.
Our Subsea segment is making steady progress in demonstrating how we can help customers improve recoveries. For this reason, we reiterate our view that Subsea orders will be at or above 2014 order levels, with the back half of the year weighted to the fourth quarter.
We believe the breadth of our portfolio will allow us to take advantage of the marketplace despite the shape or style of the recovery. We remain committed to our multiyear margin improvement program, and we believe that our ability to generate solid results thus far during a tough market is a clear indication that we are on the right path.
On that note, I'll turn it over to Chuck.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter of this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments. Subsea was up 4% sequentially. Revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter of this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments. Subsea was up 4% sequentially. Revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-to-quarter. Revenues in Surface and V&M were down sequentially about 6% and 11%, respectively. The good news is that the pace of the declines in our shorter-cycle components of Surface and V&M seem to be moderating.
EBIT margins before other costs were 12.1% for the quarter, which is 50 basis points higher when compared to the year quarter -- year-ago quarter, down sequentially about 70 basis points. No surprise there as our Surface business reflects the level of North American activity declines. However, it appears that Surface margins may have bottomed in Q2. As both Jack and Scott mentioned, we've been working on fundamentally lowering our cost structure since early '14, and our second quarter results show further evidence of our progress in this regard.
Consolidated SG&A expense was down 16% versus year-ago quarter and also modestly below the level of Q1. Operating EPS was $0.83, which is below the year-ago quarter and below the first quarter of this year. That's no surprise given the market conditions. Excluding -- excluded from operating earnings are other costs amounting to $0.12 per share primarily for restructuring cost, devaluation of the Angolan currency and accelerated write-downs of underutilized assets. 
Now a few words about each segment. Subsea revenues declined from the levels of the year-ago quarter due to the timing of project deliveries. That being said, revenues increased on a sequential basis as expected. Q1 represented the seasonal low point for Subsea revenues. Operating income margin came in at 10.2%, almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and also above Q1 due to improved execution and cost reduction. 
Surface revenues were down versus the year-ago quarter and on a sequential quarter basis due largely to the weakness in the shorter-cycle North American market. The North American revenues for Surface, which accounted for -- which account for most of the shorter-cycle businesses, were down 41% from the year-ago quarter and down 19% from the preceding quarter. Our international market actually grew on both a year-over-year and sequential basis.  The operating income margin for Surface was 13.5%. Q2 margin reflects continued weakness in activity levels in North America as well as pricing pressure. Operating income margin for Surface in Q2 was also negatively impacted by FX losses, which lowered the margin by 80 basis points. For sake of clarity, what I'm referring to as FX losses represent balance sheet remeasurement of our net monetary positions in that segment.
In Drilling, no surprise on the revenue front. Revenues were 6% below the level of a year ago but essentially flat sequentially. The decline in revenues versus the year-ago quarter was driven by our shorter-cycle services businesses as the steep reduction activity levels have clearly affected our Drilling customers' spending patterns. The operating income margin in Drilling was 16.6%, which is almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and clearly shows the improved execution in this business. The Q2 margin was down on a sequential quarter basis due primarily to FX losses, which lowered Drilling's operating income margin by approximately 100 basis points.
In our V&M segment, revenues declined sharply in comparison to the year-ago quarter and the first quarter '15. Again, this should come as no surprise to anyone given the weakness in the North American market. North American revenues for V&M, which represent most of its shorter-cycle businesses, were down about 19% as compared to the preceding quarter and 33% down from the year-ago quarter. As Scott mentioned, we've begun to see signs that the North American portion of this business has begun to stabilize. Operating income margin in V&M was 11.5%, which is modestly up from the level of Q1 as expected. Net sequential quarter improvement is attributable to cost-reduction efforts. The Q2 margin was well below the level of a year ago, reflecting the impact of the de-stocking of distributor inventories in North America. Corporate expense declined by $15 million from year-ago levels, reflecting our strategic shift to a lower-cost operating model. The company ended the quarter with cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments totaling $1.7 billion and a net debt-to-cap ratio of 17%. Cameron's overall liquidity gives us significant flexibility to deal with the uncertainties presented by this down-cycle, execute on our strategic initiatives and position ourselves for growth.
Cameron's CapEx was $41 million in the second quarter as compared to $73 million in the second quarter '14. As of the end of the second quarter '15, approximately $285 million remained under our share repurchase program.
Now let's turn to outlook. Overall revenues in Q3 and 4 should hover around the levels of Q2. As far as overall EBIT margin goes, Q3 should remain around the level of Q2 before we see a slight uptick in Q4.
On that note, let's look at each of the 4 segments.  In our Subsea segment, we expect to see revenues in the second half of '15 that are well above first half levels, with Subsea's operating income margin for the second half topping 10%. In our Surface segment, we are likely to see second half revenues that are somewhat lower than half 1. We believe that Q2 is likely to be the low point for Surface margins this year and could see slight increases for Q3 and 4. In our Drilling segment, second half revenues are likely to be moderately below half 1 levels, maybe around 10% lower. We think the operating income margin will increase in each of the remaining quarters and could approach 20% in Q4. In our Valves & Measurement segment, second half revenues are likely to be somewhat below half 1, with quarterly margins not varying materially from the level of Q2.
A few other '15 items to mention. Corporate expenses should be approximately $100 million for the year, which is $10 million lower than our previous guidance of $110 million. Interest expense should approximate $140 million, and our segment revenues should approximate $200 million. The corresponding amount of intercompany operating income to eliminate would be roughly $50 million. Our operating tax rate should approximate 23%. Our CapEx will be in the approximate range from $300 million to $350 million, and noncontrolling interest should be around $50 million.
With that, Scott, let's open up for questions.

Really, with the OneSubsea formation, right, we've always said we want to optimize the Pore to Process approach for deepwater developments. And really, this is just one link in the chain to do that, right? So originally, we brought the reservoir and the SPS together with Schlumberger and Cameron, then we went to life of field just because we saw tremendous opportunities in life of field, so we partnered with Helix who is leading that. And really, the focus there and the focus at the beginning was always around driving more out of deepwater development, so improving recovery rates and helping operators get more out of existing assets. And then now, today, in this environment where cost is really the largest focus, we do think there's opportunities between the SPS, right, the production system and the SURF equipment to drive cost down and improve the installability of what we're putting on the seafloor. So I think it's -- really, for us, it's a natural progression. Again, we've said from the beginning we really want to work on helping operators from Pore to Process, and this is a nice next step for us.

componenttext: Yes, I'd just say, Ole, that for us, right, with the breadth of Cameron and how we can play in both the onshore and offshore, we're almost -- it's a little bit irrelevant to us. And so we think we're well positioned for North American onshore recovery, but at the same time, the deepwater markets do move forward and move forward quickly. We've got the portfolio and we've got everything in place to take advantage of that. So I think we've got a nice, balanced perspective here. I don't think we're saying one is going to happen any sooner than the other, but I'll just say the message is we're prepared for either way and whatever shape that the recovery takes place, and we're going to be there when it comes back.

componenttextpreview: If I can follow up on the boosting again, it does seem like there's been a pretty sharp acceleration in operator acceptance of the technology. But what would you attribute that to? Is that a focus of -- on cost savings in a lower oil price environment? Or
componenttext: If I can follow up on the boosting again, it does seem like there's been a pretty sharp acceleration in operator acceptance of the technology. But what would you attribute that to? Is that a focus of -- on cost savings in a lower oil price environment? Or is that maturity and proven reliability of the technology? Is it just successful? What would you attribute it to?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really all of the above, and I'll just start with -- we've had boosting now for a long time. We've had pumps on the seafloor for more than 15 years, and we've got 36 systems now operating around the world. So we've got an incredible track record
componenttext: Yes, it's really all of the above, and I'll just start with -- we've had boosting now for a long time. We've had pumps on the seafloor for more than 15 years, and we've got 36 systems now operating around the world. So we've got an incredible track record. We've got a lot of data on the reliability side. Our mean time between failures exceeded everybody's expectation in terms of when you have to remove the pump and put a new one in. And so we're just getting a lot of traction on the technology, and the reliability data is selling itself. I mean, additionally, right, we showed -- we publicly stated our projects with Exxon and Chevron and Total. And when you have names like that, that are endorsing our product, it allows us to really push that with smaller customers that might not have the technical appetite for risk there. So I think it's a lot of maturity. But also, given the current marketplace, right, if we can get more oil out of existing reservoir and existing developments without putting massive CapEx down, it can change the returns on those developments. And so those are great discussions to be having right now, and our guys are very busy talking to operators about how to improve their recovery rates.

componenttext: No, we do have a couple of new people in new roles leading divisions, but at the same time, our Drilling leadership has been in place for 1.5 years. And really, there was just a very strong focus on execution. We had a very large backlog, and we had a couple of pinch points and constrainments, and we've just worked very hard operationally to get those sorted and make sure that we can flow product through our different facilities there. On the Valve side, we've got a new leader at the beginning of this year. And as Chuck said, he's really taken a holistic look at the Valve business. And while that historically has been a tremendous success for Cameron, there's also room for opportunities. And so I think during a downturn and a down-cycle, it's a great time to implement change. And Doug and his team are absolutely focused on what are the markets and where do we want to play, how do we have a sales force that can connect our products to those markets, investing in technology in the Valve portfolio and then making sure that his team is aligned around all of those goals within there. So I just think it's -- I mean, at the corporate side, right, we've talked about large SG&A and transforming what we're doing on the corporate side. And those initiatives are going well, and we kicked those off in earnest just under a year ago, and we're really moving toward driving some -- leveraging the entire Cameron enterprise across our functional spending.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Scott. No, it's definitely on the standard SPS equipment, so that's your trees and manifolds. And look, it's intense. And you think about it, in 2012 and '13, you're booking 400-plus trees a year. In 2014, you're down to 230 trees, and this y
componenttext: Yes, this is Scott. No, it's definitely on the standard SPS equipment, so that's your trees and manifolds. And look, it's intense. And you think about it, in 2012 and '13, you're booking 400-plus trees a year. In 2014, you're down to 230 trees, and this year, it's going to be 200 trees. So we're in a massive overcapacity position from a tree capacity standpoint. So the standard items have heavy pricing pressure. We're doing absolutely the best we can to work with our partners and the customers that we have to hold our margins, drive standard solutions that helps everybody, drives our cost down while preserving our margin. But the environment today on pricing is not easy.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then second, can you give us a sense -- when you're talking to clients about the opportunity to enhance recovery rates in the deepwater, is there a benchmark you use? And another service company today talked about sort of the incremental dollars per p
componenttext: And then second, can you give us a sense -- when you're talking to clients about the opportunity to enhance recovery rates in the deepwater, is there a benchmark you use? And another service company today talked about sort of the incremental dollars per percentage increase in recoverables. Without getting that specific, but is there a sort of benchmark you see as far as percentage increase in recoverables that's possible with existing and then, hopefully, going forward, what that could look like?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think every reservoir is different. And I'll just add that the beauty of OneSubsea, right, and having a partner like Schlumberger is we do have a team that really understands the reservoir and understands the flow aspects and flow assurance side of
componenttext: Yes. I think every reservoir is different. And I'll just add that the beauty of OneSubsea, right, and having a partner like Schlumberger is we do have a team that really understands the reservoir and understands the flow aspects and flow assurance side of that. And we can have meaningful discussions with operators around what we think their developments can do and what the potential on that. So we feel very good about that. When we think of deepwater versus onshore recovery rates, in the deepwater, the best wells are still in the teens to maybe 20%, whereas onshore, you're getting upwards of 30% to 50% recovery. So the goal is to convert deepwater wells and get them ultimately to look something like the onshore wells. We think we can do that by putting energy on the seafloor and being able to intervene in those wells on a regular basis to help stimulate production. So there's not one magic number. There's not a benchmark we talk about, but when we think and sit down with operators and really start to understand what their reservoir characteristics are, we ultimately think that we can improve their recovery rates, and we talk about different solutions to do that.

And can you just help us understand how far along you are on the process of achieving those costs to potentially see some of these orders go ahead?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think it is true, right? So with the IOCs, where we're having a lot of success is being able to sit down with them on kind of portfolio projects that they've put on the sideline right now. And it's not necessarily around cost reduction, but it's
componenttext: Yes. So I think it is true, right? So with the IOCs, where we're having a lot of success is being able to sit down with them on kind of portfolio projects that they've put on the sideline right now. And it's not necessarily around cost reduction, but it's really around what their rate of return is and their hurdle rate internally. That's adjusted for all the risk factors and the macro environment with oil pricing and political or geographic and political risks. And so what we're doing is sitting down with teams with the IOCs and say, okay, well, let us look at this one, and maybe you've got a wrong assumption there on pump life or a different assumption on flow assurance and going back through all their assumptions that built their model and then also putting standardized solutions there that will drive costs down, putting energy on the seafloor and potentially changing the way the SPS looks like on the seafloor. Now with Subsea 7, right, we now have the ability to talk about the handover and the interfaces on the SURF side and the installability of that system. And so now we can drive -- we can talk about bringing cost down and bringing recovery rates up, which ultimately generates higher IRR, which is really what the IOCs are after.

Thank you, Christine. I would like to make a few closing comments before ending the call today. Just to say the least, there's a very challenging market for our industry. I'm very proud of the manner in which our team has met and led in meeting these challenges head-on. And I firmly believe that what would differentiate the winners in this market and in the ultimate recovery is the resolve to transform your cost structure to meet today's reality as well as leverage the recovery and beyond. To develop customer relationships that are truly built on the value of what you deliver, you must be relentless on execution, innovation, quality and service excellence. Cameron's very fortunate to have a management team that gets this, and leading this effort is Scott Rowe, who has been instrumental in driving our performance across all of these fronts.
As you all know, Scott will transition in the role of the CEO in October as I move into the role of Chairman. And each of you on this call, along with the rest of our stakeholders, can be assured that Scott's passion for excellence, along with a genuine gift to lead people and organizations, will ensure that Cameron will outperform in this cycle and well beyond. It's been a privilege and an honor to have had the opportunity to lead a great company like Cameron, and I thank all of you for your support along that journey. Thanks.

Thank you, Christine. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cameron Second Quarter Earnings Call. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, you'll hear from Jack Moore, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cameron; Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chuck Sledge, Senior VP and Chief Financial Officer. Jack, Scott and Chuck will offer commentary on the results for the quarter, and then we'll open up the line for your questions.
In accordance with the safe harbor provisions of the securities laws, we caution you that some of the statements made on this call may be forward-looking in nature and, as such, are subject to various factors not under the control of the company. For a more complete description of these factors and the related risks and uncertainties, please refer to Cameron's annual report on Form 10-K, the company's most recent Form 10-Q and today's earnings news release.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. The company generated solid second quarter earnings and orders despite the significant challenges in today's markets. Specifically, we reported fully diluted earnings per share, excluding other costs, of $0.83 for the second quarter of 2015 compared to the $0.95 we earned in the second quarter of 2014.
Our financial results reflect a strong execution across the enterprise, specifically driven by our Subsea and Drilling segments. In addition, we continue to realize the benefits from our systemic cost-reduction programs across the Cameron enterprise that resulted in a 16% decline in our SG&A expense from a year ago.
Cyclical downturn continues to create uncertainty across all of the markets we serve, especially in relation to our shorter-cycle businesses. Broadly speaking, that uncertainty has caused demand to remain muted. Additionally, we continue to see pricing pressure across all of our business segments.
Onshore markets have continued to be weak in North America, but we are seeing some evidence that the cycle may be approaching a trough. One reason we say that is that we have seen a deceleration in the rate of order declines in our onshore North America businesses. Specifically, orders for North American onshore declined only 9% from Q1 to Q2 as compared to a roughly 40% decline from Q4 to Q1. As we've previously said, international markets have proved to be a bit more resilient, and we actually saw an uptick in new orders internationally from our Surface Systems businesses from Q1 to Q2.
When we look at the offshore markets, we continue to see demand for drilling products contract sharply when we compared to the year-ago quarter. That said, we did see a sequential quarter uptick in our orders for our Drilling Systems business.
In our Subsea business, the story is much more positive this quarter, with orders up both sequentially and as compared to the year-ago period. And while both timing and scope of deepwater production systems remains a question, our OneSubsea continues to see a healthy prospect list for Subsea processing awards. Strength of the prospect list in our OneSubsea joint venture is a reflection of the competitive advantages of our offering. And again, more broadly, as both producers and suppliers collaborate to lower capital cost, increased recovery and reduce the cost per barrel, we believe many of these projects should ultimately move forward.
Now to take a step back and think about the bigger picture for Cameron, we're very fortunate to have a diverse offering of products and services that allows us to participate in the broader markets, both onshore and offshore, that make up our customer spending. To put a finer point on it, this means that Cameron is poised to benefit regardless of which particular end market recovers first.
We're encouraged by what we think are early signs of moderation in the pace of the decline in customer spending. As we have said previously, in the current environment, we remain focused on the things that we can control: ongoing systemic reduction in our cost structure, excellence in execution, creating and maintaining strong customer relationships, growing our core platforms and steady investment in new technology. We believe this focus will ensure that the company generates long-term value for all of our stakeholders.
I will now turn over the discussion to Scott Rowe, our President and Chief Operating Officer. Scott?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. I'll briefly echo Jack's comments on the company's quarterly financial performance. We did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment. We made hard decisions. We moved quickly. We're doing wh
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. I'll briefly echo Jack's comments on the company's quarterly financial performance. We did execute very well. The organization did what it needed to do in this challenging environment. We made hard decisions. We moved quickly. We're doing what we need to do, and we did all of this while embracing our customers during this difficult time.
I'll let Chuck walk you through the details of our earnings, but I do want to talk a bit about Cameron's orders. The headline here is that on a consolidated basis, orders increased 15% sequentially. In our Subsea segment, orders were 32% above the first quarter of 2015, and the book-to-bill ratio for the Subsea segment was well above 1. Clearly, OneSubsea has maintained good momentum through this cyclical downturn. Second quarter accomplishments include a $330 million award for subsea production equipment for a project offshore North Africa; a front-end engineering design contract with Woodside for a proposed floating LNG development offshore Northwest Australia. The Woodside order is particularly exciting for us because it's the first contract we have won under the frame agreement we signed with them a year ago, and we expect more to come under this agreement. 
The signing of an alliance agreement with Subsea 7 to further round out the OneSubsea portfolio. The alliance will work closely with our clients to optimize the subsea production hardware and the subsea umbilicals, risers and flowlines and drive cost-effective solutions for operators. This is a further link in the chain of our Pore to Process approach that aimed at reducing development cost for our customers and, as importantly, improving the recovery factor in deepwater developments.
Additionally, the signing of the agreement with Chevron to form a joint industry program to develop subsea technology for 20K applications. This is a natural migration of Cameron's high-pressure technology that we have already developed and deployed in our Drilling and Surface businesses.
And finally, as we're announcing today, a significant award within the quarter for a subsea boosting system in the Gulf of Mexico. We'll provide more details on this award in an upcoming press release.
Looking at our other segments, orders were also up on a sequential basis for Surface and Drilling by 5% and 23%, respectively. The increase in Surface was driven by international new equipment orders. The increase in Drilling was aided by gains in services and new equipment, including several jack-up orders. 
Orders in Valves & Measurement declined sequentially by about 5%, which is broadly reflective of what we are seeing in terms of overall demand.
In the execution front, our operations teams are performing well within the context of what is happening in this marketplace, with our customers and the competition. Specifically, we continue to execute our downturn playbook that we had put together last year, outlining a program to build better customer relations, develop technology for the future, optimize our internal processes and drive down our cost structure.
Let me cite a few examples on this. As the first playbook relates to customers, I will say that we are having the kinds of discussions today that we would never had a year ago, discussions that are much more collaborative and often coming much earlier in the life of the cycle of a project. Customers and suppliers are working together to eliminate some of the inefficiencies that crept into the business in the era of high oil prices. Many of our customer discussions are about finding specific ways to improve operational efficiencies and to improve the return on capital for their investments. Clearly, operators today realize that collaboration with suppliers has the potential to unlock new and creative approaches that will save money and generate returns in this market. Our ultimate objective in this discussion is an outcome that reduces cost for the customer while enabling Cameron to gain share and maintain margin, in other words, a win-win situation.
The playbook in relation to new technology is essentially this, a commitment to maintain our R&D spending throughout the cycle. We believe that technology spending is essential for us to retain our competitive advantages. We've seen some of these results with our recent accomplishments: first, the world's first gas compressor -- wet gas compressor for which we won an OTC Spotlight award; Mark IV High Availability Control POD for BOPs, which also won an OTC Spotlight award; the industry's first and only 13-5/8" 25K blowout preventer and the first to market with a 25K surface production system; a joint technology program between OneSubsea and Helix to engineer and manufacture a 15K intervention riser system; as well as a 20K joint industry program with Chevron that I mentioned a moment ago.
The last element of our downturn playbook is our company-wide effort to reduce our fundamental cost structure. This effort started prior to the downturn and has helped us minimize the margin impact on our businesses. Essentially, we have taken a fresh look at everything we do and challenged ourselves to drive efficiency throughout our organization. As a practical matter, what this means is that we are streamlining internal processes and organizations. We're significantly reducing the cost structure of the organization through reorganization, improved processes and leveraging the entire Cameron enterprise. One visible example of this is the 16% reduction in our SG&A, as Jack cited earlier. We will continue to do what we need to do to rightsize our business in this environment while creating a scalable model that will allow us to grow profitably -- will allow us to grow more profitably than in past up-cycles when the recovery ultimately does come.
Again, overall market conditions are challenging, but we are seeing signs of activity stabilizing in North America, and that will help our onshore-focused businesses, which include Surface, Valves & Measurement and portions of our Drilling segment, recover relatively quickly once we see activity levels actually increase.
Our Subsea segment is making steady progress in demonstrating how we can help customers improve recoveries. For this reason, we reiterate our view that Subsea orders will be at or above 2014 order levels, with the back half of the year weighted to the fourth quarter.
We believe the breadth of our portfolio will allow us to take advantage of the marketplace despite the shape or style of the recovery. We remain committed to our multiyear margin improvement program, and we believe that our ability to generate solid results thus far during a tough market is a clear indication that we are on the right path.
On that note, I'll turn it over to Chuck.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter of this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments. Subsea was up 4% sequentially. Revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Consolidated revenues for the quarter were $2.2 billion, essentially flat with the first quarter of this year, reflecting a mixed pattern among our 4 segments. Subsea was up 4% sequentially. Revenues in drilling were basically flat quarter-to-quarter. Revenues in Surface and V&M were down sequentially about 6% and 11%, respectively. The good news is that the pace of the declines in our shorter-cycle components of Surface and V&M seem to be moderating.
EBIT margins before other costs were 12.1% for the quarter, which is 50 basis points higher when compared to the year quarter -- year-ago quarter, down sequentially about 70 basis points. No surprise there as our Surface business reflects the level of North American activity declines. However, it appears that Surface margins may have bottomed in Q2. As both Jack and Scott mentioned, we've been working on fundamentally lowering our cost structure since early '14, and our second quarter results show further evidence of our progress in this regard.
Consolidated SG&A expense was down 16% versus year-ago quarter and also modestly below the level of Q1. Operating EPS was $0.83, which is below the year-ago quarter and below the first quarter of this year. That's no surprise given the market conditions. Excluding -- excluded from operating earnings are other costs amounting to $0.12 per share primarily for restructuring cost, devaluation of the Angolan currency and accelerated write-downs of underutilized assets. 
Now a few words about each segment. Subsea revenues declined from the levels of the year-ago quarter due to the timing of project deliveries. That being said, revenues increased on a sequential basis as expected. Q1 represented the seasonal low point for Subsea revenues. Operating income margin came in at 10.2%, almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and also above Q1 due to improved execution and cost reduction. 
Surface revenues were down versus the year-ago quarter and on a sequential quarter basis due largely to the weakness in the shorter-cycle North American market. The North American revenues for Surface, which accounted for -- which account for most of the shorter-cycle businesses, were down 41% from the year-ago quarter and down 19% from the preceding quarter. Our international market actually grew on both a year-over-year and sequential basis.  The operating income margin for Surface was 13.5%. Q2 margin reflects continued weakness in activity levels in North America as well as pricing pressure. Operating income margin for Surface in Q2 was also negatively impacted by FX losses, which lowered the margin by 80 basis points. For sake of clarity, what I'm referring to as FX losses represent balance sheet remeasurement of our net monetary positions in that segment.
In Drilling, no surprise on the revenue front. Revenues were 6% below the level of a year ago but essentially flat sequentially. The decline in revenues versus the year-ago quarter was driven by our shorter-cycle services businesses as the steep reduction activity levels have clearly affected our Drilling customers' spending patterns. The operating income margin in Drilling was 16.6%, which is almost 400 basis points above the year-ago quarter and clearly shows the improved execution in this business. The Q2 margin was down on a sequential quarter basis due primarily to FX losses, which lowered Drilling's operating income margin by approximately 100 basis points.
In our V&M segment, revenues declined sharply in comparison to the year-ago quarter and the first quarter '15. Again, this should come as no surprise to anyone given the weakness in the North American market. North American revenues for V&M, which represent most of its shorter-cycle businesses, were down about 19% as compared to the preceding quarter and 33% down from the year-ago quarter. As Scott mentioned, we've begun to see signs that the North American portion of this business has begun to stabilize. Operating income margin in V&M was 11.5%, which is modestly up from the level of Q1 as expected. Net sequential quarter improvement is attributable to cost-reduction efforts. The Q2 margin was well below the level of a year ago, reflecting the impact of the de-stocking of distributor inventories in North America. Corporate expense declined by $15 million from year-ago levels, reflecting our strategic shift to a lower-cost operating model. The company ended the quarter with cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments totaling $1.7 billion and a net debt-to-cap ratio of 17%. Cameron's overall liquidity gives us significant flexibility to deal with the uncertainties presented by this down-cycle, execute on our strategic initiatives and position ourselves for growth.
Cameron's CapEx was $41 million in the second quarter as compared to $73 million in the second quarter '14. As of the end of the second quarter '15, approximately $285 million remained under our share repurchase program.
Now let's turn to outlook. Overall revenues in Q3 and 4 should hover around the levels of Q2. As far as overall EBIT margin goes, Q3 should remain around the level of Q2 before we see a slight uptick in Q4.
On that note, let's look at each of the 4 segments.  In our Subsea segment, we expect to see revenues in the second half of '15 that are well above first half levels, with Subsea's operating income margin and the second half topping 10%. In our Surface segment, we are likely to see second half revenues that are somewhat lower than half 1. We believe that Q2 is likely to be the low point for Surface margins this year and could see slight increases for Q3 and 4. In our Drilling segment, second half revenues are likely to be moderately below half 1 levels, maybe around 10% lower. We think the operating income margin will increase in each of the remaining quarters and could approach 20% in Q4. In our Valves & Measurement segment, second half revenues are likely to be somewhat below half 1, with quarterly margins not varying materially from the level of Q2.
A few other '15 items to mention. Corporate expenses should be approximately $100 million for the year, which is $10 million lower than our previous guidance of $110 million. Interest expense should approximate $140 million, and our segment revenues should approximate $200 million. The corresponding amount of intercompany operating income to eliminate would be roughly $50 million. Our operating tax rate should approximate 23%. Our CapEx will be in the approximate range from $300 million to $350 million, and noncontrolling interest should be around $50 million.
With that, Scott, let's open up for questions.

componenttext: Yes, sure, Jeff. This is Scott. I'll answer that. Really, with the OneSubsea formation, right, we've always said we want to optimize the Pore to Process approach for deepwater developments. And really, this is just one link in the chain to do that, right? So originally, we brought the reservoir and the SPS together with Schlumberger and Cameron, then we went to life of field just because we saw tremendous opportunities in life of field, so we partnered with Helix who is leading that. And really, the focus there and the focus at the beginning was always around driving more out of deepwater development, so improving recovery rates and helping operators get more out of existing assets. And then now, today, in this environment where cost is really the largest focus, we do think there's opportunities between the SPS, right, the production system and the SURF equipment to drive cost down and improve the installability of what we're putting on the seafloor. So I think it's -- really, for us, it's a natural progression. Again, we've said from the beginning we really want to work on helping operators from Pore to Process, and this is a nice next step for us.

componenttext: Yes, I'd just say, Ole, that for us, right, with the breadth of Cameron and how we can play in both the onshore and offshore, we're almost -- it's a little bit irrelevant to us. And so we think we're well positioned for North American onshore recovery, but at the same time, if the deepwater markets do move forward and move forward quickly. We've got the portfolio and we've got everything in place to take advantage of that. So I think we've got a nice, balanced perspective here. I don't think we're saying one is going to happen any sooner than the other, but I'll just say the message is we're prepared for either way and whatever shape that the recovery takes place, and we're going to be there when it comes back.

componenttextpreview: If I can follow up on the boosting again, it does seem like there's been a pretty sharp acceleration in operator acceptance of the technology. But what would you attribute that to? Is that a focus of -- on cost savings in a lower oil price environment? Or
componenttext: If I can follow up on the boosting again, it does seem like there's been a pretty sharp acceleration in operator acceptance of the technology. But what would you attribute that to? Is that a focus of -- on cost savings in a lower oil price environment? Or is that maturity and proven reliability of the technology? Is it just successful? What would you attribute it to?

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really all of the above, and I'll just start with -- we've had boosting now for a long time. We've had pumps on the seafloor for more than 15 years, and we've got 36 systems now operating around the world. So we've got an incredible track record
componenttext: Yes, it's really all of the above, and I'll just start with -- we've had boosting now for a long time. We've had pumps on the seafloor for more than 15 years, and we've got 36 systems now operating around the world. So we've got an incredible track record. We've got a lot of data on the reliability side. Our mean time between failures exceeded everybody's expectation in terms of when you have to remove the pump and put a new one in. And so we're just getting a lot of traction on the technology, and the reliability data is selling itself. I mean, additionally, right, we showed -- we publicly stated our projects with Exxon and Chevron and Total. And when you have names like that, that are endorsing our product, it allows us to really push that with smaller customers that might not have the technical appetite for risk there. So I think it's a lot of maturity. But also, given the current marketplace, right, if we can get more oil out of existing reservoir and existing developments without putting massive CapEx down, it can change the returns on those developments. And so those are great discussions to be having right now, and our guys are very busy talking to operators about how to improve their recovery rates.

headline: Cameron International Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we do have a couple of new people in new roles leading divisions, but at the same time, our Drilling leadership has been in place for 1.5 years. And really, there was just a very strong focus on execution. We had a very large backlog, and we had a cou
componenttext: No, we do have a couple of new people in new roles leading divisions, but at the same time, our Drilling leadership has been in place for 1.5 years. And really, there was just a very strong focus on execution. We had a very large backlog, and we had a couple of pinch points and constrainments, and we've just worked very hard operationally to get those sorted and make sure that we can flow product through our different facilities there. On the Valve side, we've got a new leader at the beginning of this year. And as Chuck said, he's really taken a holistic look at the Valve business. And while that historically has been a tremendous success for Cameron, there's also room for opportunities. And so I think during a downturn and a down-cycle, it's a great time to implement change. And Doug and his team are absolutely focused on what are the markets and where do we want to play, how do we have a sales force that can connect our products to those markets, investing in technology in the Valve portfolio and then making sure that his team is aligned around all of those goals within there. So I just think it's -- I mean, at the corporate side, right, we've talked about large SG&A and transforming what we're doing on the corporate side. And those initiatives are going well, and we kicked those off in earnest just under a year ago, and we're really moving toward driving some -- leveraging the entire Cameron enterprise across our functional spending.

componenttext: Sure. So our Valve business does go -- it covers -- we've got a large portfolio in the upstream side, but we're actively in the midstream player with the pipelines and then a smaller percentage on the downstream side. But currently, the downstream segment is doing very well, and it's robust, and we've been able to grow that this year. We do see opportunities midstream internationally, and we ultimately believe that the rewiring in North America is not complete and that as activity does increase in North America, you see our Distributed Valves pick up quickly. Then also you get the midstream effect there as you're rewiring production to get from where that's developed to the refining basins.

componenttext: Well, a couple of things. It's really not seasonal, so that is -- that's just -- we were successful at capturing share, and again, as we've said, activity levels have stabilized.
